Ottawa, November 29th, 1909.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, enclosing a communication from Mr. Agent Loring in reference to the establishment of a Roman Catholic Day School for the Babine Indians, and in reply I beg to say that the Department will await the detailed report asked for in its letter of the 16th ultimo before taking any action in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

A. W. Vowell, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Victoria, B.C.
Memo - The proposed School Building, at Sabine, is facing the lake to the east, and thus forms less resistance to the gales raging at times from north to south through the gap of the mountains in the course of the Sabine river.

The site is an ideal one, and readily can be improved upon by the planting of poplars lopped off on top to give them breadth.

The building, on the lines proposed, can be made perfect, and in compliance with Departmental instructions its doors are given as opening outward.

Memo - A log building would be much cheaper and more desirable than one of frame. To prevent such to get out of shape, it must be made to rest on blocks sunk below the depth of frost. According to sketch, thereupon are made to rest the foundation logs overlapping and mortised.

In the mortises are made to fit the 6 perpendicular logs with grooves of 5" wide and 3" deep wherein to receive those of horizontal line, fitted with tongue, by being slid from the top down in the grooves.

Moss is to be used as packing between each successive log going on in this wise, and the pressure will make the walls as tight as they can be made.

The log plates are fitted to the top in mortises, as such at the bottom, and render the building perfectly solid of construction by being thus practically keyed together.
Indian Office, Victoria, B.C.
February 14th, 1910.

File No. 350242/1.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 29th of November last in reference to a communication from Mr. Agent Loring of the Babine Agency in regard to the establishment of a Roman Catholic Day School for the Babine Indians, I have the honour to enclose herewith for the information and consideration of the Department a report in the premises dated the 8th ultimo today received from the Agent with enclosures therein referred to.

Upon looking over the enclosed correspondence from Mr. Agent Loring it is perceived that he has been at great pains to make the matter as plain as possible to the Department concerning the requirements of the Indians referred to. Considering the locality and the excessive cost of living there his estimate of $3335.95 for the cost of the proposed building seems to me quite reasonable as it must be borne in mind that much of the material will have to be imported at a heavy cost of transport, while for the material procured locally, such as logs, etc., require in their manipulation much skilled labour which is necessarily high in that portion of the Superintendency.

As these

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
As these Indians are making every endeavour to better their condition and as it is necessary in view of the rapid settlement of the country in that portion of the Province, I would earnestly recommend that authority be granted at the earliest possible date for the commencement of the structure so that the same may be completed and utilized for the purpose intended before next Fall.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Supt. of Indian Affairs, B.C.
Sir,

In result of a conference, on the 16th of July last, between the Assistant Secretary of the Department, yourself, Chief Teach William and other Indians of both Forts Babine and myself, at this Agency, attending, and according your letter #204, R-5, dated the 8th of October last, concerning inter alia a school being established, at Fort Babine, I have the honour to enclose herewith plans of ground floor, elevation and estimates and specifications, in duplicate, respectively.

In discrimination to all submitted, many of the most profitable and practical features, adapted to local conditions, etc., etc., were derived consequent the erection of the salmon hatchery building on Babine lake.

The delay in this matter was occasioned by corresponding with the Revd. Fathers Nunez, O.M.I., and M. Coccola, Stuart Lake Mission, Stuart Lake, B.C.

Thereafter, I had to await the latter's arrival here, on the 13th ultimo. Then, in endeavouring to get at the cost of the material, interviewed the Manager of Hazelton Post, Hudson's Bay Company, and found that he could not give me the price of a pair of hinges, at the selling price, at Babine.

And, since the lumber has to be whipsawed by the Indians there, and they have no conception of running feet, but only according arrangements by the piece, I finally had to resort to get all my information by corresponding with the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company's Post of that locality.

The main body of the proposed school building there is desired to be of logs for reasons of avoiding as much as possible the high

A. W. VOWELL, ESQ.
Superintendent of Indian Affairs, B.C., &c.

VICTORIA,
B.C.
high cost of lumber there, and have a warmer building for the winter and much cooler for the extremely hot weather during the summers.

On estimating the cost thereof, complete, it will amount, in summary, to $5,555.95. This amount may seem large, but such is not the case, considering that the material has to be whipawed and dressed by hand; also, primarily, the material is for some distance to be brought; besides the cost of hardware, imported at high rate, etc., is considerable.

Aside of the foregoing, but appositely in connection with the establishment of the said school by the Department, I here beg leave to recommend that the Teacher's salary should be no less than $600.00, or better $800.00 per annum, for reasons of extraordinary costs of subsistence in the locality referred to.

The building will afford the Teacher's residence.

Upon the establishment of this school, it is calculated to serve for the attendance of children of Fort Babine and Old Fort Babine alike, of whom there are, of school age, 48, collectively, or about 24 belonging to each.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

CANADA
Sir,— I have the honour to enclose herewith voucher No. 62, for $15.00, in favour of Babine Post, Hudson's Bay Company, for transport furnished Mr. Joseph F. Morrissey, teacher of the Fort Babine Indian Day School, from here thither, upon my request.

In regard thereto, I beg to state that with Departmental letter, dated the 27th of August, last, I received simultaneously one of the 4th ultimo from the Right Revd. Father E. M. Bunoz, O.M.I., Prince Rupert; and at their receipt, the said teacher presented himself in person, at the same time, to boot.

By the tone of the said correspondence, I thought myself called upon at once, and hastened to Rocher Deboulé (same day, 9th ultimo) to interview Revd. Father Godfrey in behalf of the teacher, but the former was absent in the Bulkley valley.

Mr. Morrissey confided to me that he had neither the means to stay here, go forward, or to go back on; thereat I found myself in a quandary what to do.

Through my personal interposition with Mr. Leslie Laing, Manager of Fort Babine Post, who happened to be here at the time, I made the aforesaid arrangements, or otherwise Mr. Morrissey would not have been able to get in for less than $50.00 with no end of hardship, or, perhaps, not at all, since then already one heavy snow storm was had on the Babine Range of Mountains.

And beg likewise to add that all this antedated the Departmental letter of the 28th ultimo (received on the 13th instant) wherein thereafter I found it quoted, to wit:—

"I may say that the Department does not pay the charges for transport of teachers. You will be good enough to make a note of this."

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th, ult., enclosing letter from Daniel Leon requesting an increased rent for the building in which the Fort Babine School is conducted.

Kindly notify the Department when these repairs are finished and the increased rent will be paid from that date.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Provision is made in the 1946-47 Babine Agency estimates for midday meals for pupils at the Fort Babine Indian Day School. An amount of $8.00 per month during the winter months was provided for but as the enrolment has increased to 45 children, this amount will not be sufficient. Mr. Boys has recommended that the amount be increased to $15.00 per month and I concur in his recommendation and suggest that the amount be allowed for the months of November, 1946 to March, 1947 inclusive, a total of $75.00.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, 30 October 1946.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 26th instant, it has been decided to allow an amount of $10.00 a month for the period Nov. 1, 1946 to Mar. 31, 1947 to assist in providing a midday meal for the pupils attending the Fort Babine Indian Day School.

At those schools where the Department has previously allowed funds for midday meal purposes, we are continuing that practice. However, in view of the payment of family allowances, we feel that there is no great necessity for any heavy increase on the part of the Department as it is fair to presume the children are receiving better food at home and in many cases should be able to provide part at least, of the food required for their midday lunch.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. B. W. Waugh,

I am enclosing Branch File 151-5-5 and wish to direct your attention to Major MacKay's letter of December 16th in connection with a small parcel of land the Department wishes to purchase for school purposes on Babine Indian Reserve No. 6.

If you will refer to the reverse side of the Council resolution, you will note that Mr. Boys, the Indian Agent, has prepared a rough sketch of the area required. It would be appreciated if you would prepare a description and prints to be attached to surrender documents, as it will be necessary to have a surrender of this land before a sale can be arranged.

D. J. Allan
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

Enc.

MMeC/VB
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 151-5-5

I wish to refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of March 7th, 1946, and related correspondence in connection with the proposed construction of a new teacher's residence at Fort Babine; also to my letter of September 23rd last regarding the 1948-49 day school building program wherein reference was made to the construction of a one room day school with teacherage at Fort Babine.

In anticipation of construction being proceeded with early next year I have been corresponding with Mr. Indian Agent Boys regarding a suitable site for the school. His letters of November 3rd and December 5th and enclosures referred to, are enclosed for your information. You will note that an area of approximately 3.55 acres is plotted on a sketch of Babine L.R. No. 6 on the reverse of the Band resolution. Mr. Boys has been unable to tie the area in to a survey point without instruments and consequently without a survey it will be difficult to adequately describe the parcel for surrender purposes. I should appreciate being advised if the Department will require a surrender from the Band before payment is made to John Baptiste Lowley, Indian locatee, for his improvements, and if the description in the resolution would be acceptable for surrender purposes in this case seeing title is to remain in the Crown.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver,
B.C.

Kindly refer to your letter of November 14th, your File 1-11-3.

Enclosed herewith you will find an Agreement of Sale for the parcel of land on the Babine Indian Reserve, No. 6 which I have selected as a satisfactory School Site. You will note that John Baptiste LOWLEY the owner, has agreed to accept the sum of $75 per acre and I would suggest that a deposit of say $200 be paid to LOWLEY pending Survey following which a final settlement might be made. I would suggest that plans be sought for a School Building with Teacherage attached, plus a separate room, with an outside door to be used as accommodation for visiting officials to this remote reserve, or alternatively as a Dispensary.

I feel that the need of new accommodation at Fort Babine is very urgent and I should dearly like to see a new building erected in 1948. You will note that the sum of $16,000 was set aside in the 1947-48 Estimates for this building.

J.N. Boys
Indian Agent.

Replying to your letter of October 25th your file l-11-3 regarding a site for the Indian Day School at Fort Babine I note that it is required to tie in the plot to be surrendered with one of the corner posts of the Reserve.

Discussing the matter with you at Hazelton a few days ago I pointed out urgent need of a new school at Fort Babine and the fact that I have just returned from what will probably be my last trip to Fort Babine in 1947. You suggested that I should return the file to you and asked that the purchase be considered pending survey of the property.

It is understood that having no instruments that I can tie this lot in only very roughly and it is felt that until a further survey is made that the bridge might serve as a point of commencement.

As to the value of the land the suggestion of $100 per acre is purely tentative and I would suggest that an offer be made to Baptiste Lowley on the basis of whatever value the Director may feel is proper. Re: School Construction Projects in British Columbia
Your file 1-1-5 (E)

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of November 1st concerning the provision of school facilities at Old Fort in the Babine Agency as included on our priority list submitted to the Department some time ago.

This point is located on Babine Lake about 30 miles S.E. of Fort Babine. A school survey indicates that there are 79 children 16 years of age and under at this point. Of this number 46 are in the age group 6 to 16. The pre-school age population is 33. Although the number of school age children would appear to warrant the construction of a two room school, due to the nomadic life of many of the families it is felt that a one room would probably meet the actual need.

I might say that a school was operated at this point up until March of 1940 when the present teacher at Fort Babine was transferred from Old Fort. At the time of his transfer there were 23 pupils enrolled in the Old Fort School, with an average attendance of 11.3. The school apparently remained closed, partly because of the acute teacher shortage.

The building in use was an old structure rented from one of the natives belonging to the reserve. It is quite unsuitable for school purposes and is in very poor repair.

(sgd.) W.S. Arneil

Day School Building Programme - British Columbia.

Dear Bill:

I am still waiting anxiously for the final prints of plan 891, as I told you in my previous letter of May 16.

I have decided not to wait much longer for these plans but would suggest the action outlined below:

Fort Babine Indian Day School

As this is a school without hydro, I would suggest that we proceed immediately to advertise for the erection of this two-room school with teacherage, plan 891. Please find attached the draft advertisement which I would like you to check over and if satisfactory, we will arrange to run this advertisement at once. I would suggest that it be advertised in the two main Vancouver papers, the Prince Rupert Daily News and the Interior News at Smithers, B. C. I have marked this advertisement No. 1 and would welcome an early message indicating if advertisement No. 1 is satisfactory or any changes which you would wish to have made in it.

Hartley Bay Indian Day School
Takla Lake Indian Day School
Kincolith Indian Day School

As you are aware, a two-room school with electricity and running water is being designed and will be termed plan 891. I am sending you a draft advertisement marked No. 2 but we cannot
proceed with this advertisement until the plans are in your hands and deemed to be satisfactory. The one thing that concerns me is that the electricity is designed for hydro alternating current and I presume that the power supply at Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Lakelseap will be from a D.C. village lighting plant. I have spoken to Miss Walton about this and will get details of the lighting plants at these three villages from her if possible. I can then advise the electrical engineer accordingly.

I would welcome your comments on advertisement 2 and will hold this in readiness until you have seen the plans and wired your approval to proceed with advertising. As recommended by Mr. Anfield, this advertisement should appear in both Vancouver papers and in the Prince Rupert Daily News.

Douglas Indian Day School

Chehalis Indian Day School

These are one-room schools and teacherages and we have yet to receive the information reports. I presume that plan 888 will be followed and that both these schools could be advertised together. I have therefore drafted advertisement No. 3 which I think would cover these two projects. We should of course have the information reports first and a definite indication that water is available and that the site is satisfactory. However, I will expect a letter from you covering these two schools.

Ucluelet Indian Day School

Glascoo Indids Day School

We will write a separate letter about this based on the information on Inspector Davey's recent report.

To conclude, therefore, I feel that we can take the following action immediately:

(a) Advertise for tenders for the Fort Babine School
(b) Advertise for tenders for the Douglas and Chehalis Schools.
(c) Be prepared to advertise for Hartley Bay, Lakelsep and Kincolith Schools as soon as the plans are ready and seen by you.

I sincerely hope that the above meets with your approval and that the advertisements will draw tenders. So far we have been quite pleased with the response received to date in answer to our advertisements on the Prairies and in Eastern Canada.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Fort Babine Indian Day School

Dear Bill:

The tenders for the erection of this school have been opened, and I am rather disappointed with the results. In the first place, only one tender was received and this was from Precision Housing Co. Ltd., in Vancouver in amount of $67,391.00. Their letter read as follows:

"Enclosed please find tender for the supply and erection at the site of Fort Babine, B.C., a two classroom Indian Day School with teachers quarters. The remoteness of this location necessitates extreme precaution of the contractor as we are informed there are absolutely no facilities at Fort Babine.

Precision Housing would, due to the above, be prepared to supply and erect this building on a cost plus 15% basis or for the firm tender of $67391.00. We feel that considerable saving could be made on a cost plus basis."

As you are aware, this is much higher than any price we have been called upon as yet for a two-room school, and I would doubt very much whether authority could be obtained for its acceptance.

Do you think we could obtain a firm tender for a quonset type building for Fort Babine? If so, I could
suggest to the Director that we recommend to the Minister's Office that this Precision House Company Limited Tender be rejected as too high and that you be requested to approach the Quonset people in Vancouver for a firm price tender for the erection of a two-room school on their plan at Fort Sabine.

If you wish to reply by Army Signal that you agree with this suggestion, then I will be pleased to take action immediately in making this recommendation.

With best good wishes,

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Healy,
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Fort Babine Indian Day School.

Included in our Main Estimates is the sum of $30,000.00 for the erection of a two-room school and teacherage at Fort Babine, in the Babine Indian Agency, British Columbia.

In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, we advertised for tenders in Vancouver, Prince Rupert and Smithers newspapers.

Only one tender was received, from the Precision Housing Company, Limited, of Vancouver, B.C. Their tender was accompanied by a letter which read as follows:

"Enclosed please find tender for the supply and erection at the site of Fort Babine, B.C., a two classroom Indian Day School with teachers quarters. The remoteness of this location necessitates extreme precaution of the contractor as we are informed there are absolutely no facilities at Fort Babine.

"Precision Housing would, due to the above, be prepared to supply and erect this building on a cost plus 15% basis or for the firm tender of $67391.00. We feel that considerable saving could be made on a cost plus basis."

This price for the erection of a two-room school is considered to be very high, even in a place as relatively
isolated as Fort Babine. An airmail letter was therefore sent to Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil, advising him of this fact and suggesting that he approach the Stran-Steel Company, builders of the Quonset hut type schools. This firm's Eastern representatives have been anxious to bid on our schools, advising that they could build them for a much lower price than we are paying by standard construction. Several of the provinces have been building these Quonset type schools and we feel that if their prices are lower than standard construction, they should be tried as a mode of construction. This is particularly applicable in isolated regions where the transportation costs on the packaged steel panels are much lower than on the usual building materials.

There are two other schools on which we contemplate approaching the builders of the Quonset type schools as in these cases also tendered prices have been much higher than anticipated. Please find attached photographs and a bulletin dealing with these buildings. It is felt that our intentions in this regard should be brought to your attention as we intend to recommend the erection of some of these Quonset schools if standard building proves too expensive.

Acting Director.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a two-room Indian Day School and attached teachers' residence on the Fort Babine Indian Reserve, in the Babine Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following single tender:

Precision Housing, Limited,
Pte. McLean Drive, Vancouver, B.C. .......... $67,391.00.

THAT this company is also prepared to supply and erect this building on a cost plus 15% basis;

THAT our officials feel that this tender is too high for the erection of a two-room school and teachers' house, even on such an isolated reserve;

THAT Departmental officials have, therefore, approached National All-Steel Buildings, Limited, 1768 Hastings Street East, Vancouver, British Columbia, with the request that they tender on a Quonset type school for this reserve;

THAT such Quonset type schools are being erected by provincial departments of Education and local school boards for white children where standard school building costs are felt to be too high;

THAT National All-Steel Buildings Limited has submitted a tender for a Quonset type school with two classrooms and a teachers' house on the Fort Babine Indian Reserve in the firm amount of $22,825.00;

THAT Departmental officials have examined the plans and specifications for this Quonset type school and recommend
the acceptance of the tender of National All-Steel Buildings Limited, of Vancouver, B.C., in view of the fact that it is only one third the amount required for a school of standard construction and should provide a satisfactory school for these children;

TEST funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of National All-Steel Buildings Limited, of Vancouver, B.C., for the erection of this Quonset type two-room school and teachers' residence for the amount of $22,825.00 which, with contingencies, may amount to $25,000.00.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Re: Fort Babine Indian Day School

It will be noted that the new submission of the Maple Leaf Distributors Limited for the supply of a quonset type school for the above mentioned is completely different from the original plan. The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 12th August, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a two-room Indian Day School and attached teachers' residence on the Fort Babine Indian Reserve, in the Babine Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for the education of the Indian children living there;

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers and the following single tender received:

Precision Housing, Limited,
Ft. McLean Drive, Vancouver, B.C. $67,391.00

That this company is also prepared to supply and erect this building on a cost plus 15% basis;

That officials of the Department feel that this tender is too high for the erection of a two-room and teacherage, even on such an isolated reserve;

That Departmental officials have, therefore, approached National All-Steel Buildings, Limited, 1768 Hastings Street East, Vancouver, British Columbia, with the request that they tender on a Quonset type school for this reserve;

That such Quonset type schools are being erected by provincial departments of Education and local school boards for white children where standard school building costs are felt to be too high;

That National All-Steel Buildings Limited has submitted a tender for a Quonset type school with two classrooms and a teacherage on the Fort Babine Indian Reserve in the firm amount of $22,825.00;

That Departmental officials have examined the plans and specifications for this Quonset type school and recommend the acceptance of the tender of National All-Steel Buildings Limited, of Vancouver, B.C., in view of the fact that it is only one third the amount required for a school of standard construction and should provide a satisfactory school for these children;

That funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Honourable
the Minister of Mines and Resources

Aiyansh, 70 miles up the Nass River in a rich agricultural valley, is another place where I should like the Day School strengthened by the application of the Hon. Mr. Oliver's new policy. Right Reverend Sir,

The Department was furnished some time ago by Mr. Supt. Vowell with a copy of your letter to Mr. Agent Lorenz regarding the possibility of affording better educational facilities for the Indians of the North West Agency B.C. In your communication you suggested the improvement of the Day School on the Aiyunish Reserve and stated that the Indians were willing to set apart 170 acres of their Reserve for school purposes if something could be done to teach them farming. The Department will be willing to carry out a plan for extending the usefulness of the day schools when it is assured that the time is ripe and the conditions favorable for doing so. Full information should be forthcoming as to whether there would be a sufficient number of children permanently on the Reserve to justify the expenditure of the amount necessary to properly conduct a new type of school.

When this fact is established there is still the question of securing the services of a teacher with the necessary qualifications to carry on such a school, and the Department would like you to suggest the name of a

Right Rev. F.H. DuVernet, D.D.,

Married man for Teacher, whose wife would be able to assist in carrying out the scheme, which includes improvements in the domestic habits of the women on the Reserve; the aim being to educate the Indian children amid their native surroundings and while inculcating principles of thrift and self dependence to improve at the same time the conditions of life in their homes. It need hardly be pointed out that the success of the proposed plan depends largely on the persons selected to inaugurate it; they should capable beyond all doubt of carrying on the work in which they are to be engaged. Sir,

Absence from the mainland at Massett, Q.C.I., has delayed my answering your letters of Feb 13 and 19, No 67,340-1, and 125,342-1 which awaited my return.

I take these letters as asking for my candid opinion upon what we all feel to be a most difficult problem. Let me say first that I am most anxious to assist the Department in every possible way in carrying out their new policy of improved Day Schools. I have thought the matter over long and carefully and discussed it with some of our missionaries. I am quite willing to sacrifice denominational pride for the best interests of the Indians. Allow me to express my views freely in hope of helping the cause.

1. No one policy will suit all parts of Canada. It is necessary to modify a general policy according to local conditions. The policy of an improved day school as outlined by the Department seems to suggest the Prairies rather than British Columbia.

2. Speaking for the Church of England in Northern British Columbia let me try and explain the local conditions.

We began Christian work among the Coast Indians over fifty years ago. Our 2,300 Christianized Indians have their homes in villages, most of them live in modern houses, dress well &c. In almost every village there is a clergyman and his wife and family. The clergyman is practically a doctor.

Without

Without any remuneration he is constantly tending the sick, gives practical advice, tells them the danger of evil germs, urges them to keep their houses clean, his wife (like Mrs. Collison of Kincolith) is constantly giving the women hints in domestic matters, there is a day school in the village, usually taught by a white woman, a single lady who lives with the missionary and his wife. It would be impossible for a single lady to live elsewhere in the village. The cost of reaching these villages up the rivers &c is considerable. The freight or food &c. is excessive, and yet the Department only allows $300.00 a year, subject to reduction, to keep up this Day School, pay travelling expenses and teacher's salary. I have inspected the Day Schools at Metlacatla, Kitkatla, Massett, Kincolith, Lakkal-zap, Aiyansh, Gitwangak, Hazelton &c. and found, not as I have found east of the Rockies, three or four children in a school, but from fifteen to forty five. The younger generation of our Indians have all passed through these Day Schools and the result is far beyond what the Department could possible expect from such inadequate support. I have heard a young Indian man read the lessons in Church in English better than many white men could and yet he had had no other education than that obtained at the village day school. Viewed in the light of relative expenditure I have no hesitation in saying that there has been far greater returns from the Day School than the so called Industrial School which on the per capita system could not afford to keep first class trades instructors. It is on this ground that I appeal to the Department to use some of the money saved from the closing of our Metlacatla Industrial School and strengthen these Day Schools which under great disadvantages have accomplished so much good.

It seems
It seems invidious for me to name two of these Day Schools and leave the others out. I mentioned Massett because it is the largest Day School, 50 on the roll, and the place is 80 miles from the mainland, and Aiyansh because a school midway between Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks would answer both villages and give a good number of children but all these Day Schools should be considered and an increased grant made.

Accepting the policy of the improved Day School and applying it to our local conditions here what are the modifications necessary?

From the description given of our villages it will be seen that a nurse is scarcely needed. Some one should have authority to inspect the Indian houses and order a thorough disinfecting once or twice a year.

Except in the case of a school midway between Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks a mid-day meal does not seem necessary. Many of our Indians are adopting out food. They all have kitchen stoves. They know how to cook. They are not in want. It is mistaken policy for the Government to relieve the parents of the duty of providing for their children.

In regard to industrial training, very few of the children attending day school are old enough to profit from a course of industrial training.

The very best thing the Government could do for our Indians is to employ a first class carpenter and boat-builder and have him visit our villages in turn forming classes of young men from 16 up. Most of our Indians are very quick with tools; the Massett men build fine schooners. A skilled white man could teach them much that would be most useful in a short course. It would not be necessary to visit each village.
village each year.

Let me now mention the one great difficulty in the way of making the Day School meet the need of the ordinary Indian child. Absence from home at certain seasons. If our Indians lived all the year round in their villages there would be no need whatever for Boarding Schools or Industrial Schools except one central denominational one for a few of the most promising and perfectly sound children, but this is not the case. The cannery season from June 15 to Sept. 1st does not seriously interfere as most of this is vacation time, but in most of our villages there is another season which comes in March or April when the parents go off and take their children. They would gladly leave them behind them if we could in any way house and feed them for a few weeks. I have thought much over this and talked it over with our leading missionaries. They all agree that this is the problem.

Meet this difficulty and the Day School is all that the ordinary child needs, and the parents will not feel the separation as in the case of a distant Boarding School. "My child might as well be dead" said one mother bitterly when she found she could not get her child back for eight years.

In some cases only a few of the people go away at one time. If we had a man and his wife in charge, a tent that would hold a dozen children, with blankets &c might meet the need. I think the parents would be willing to provide food for their children during their absence. Our Missionaries are willing to co-operate as they see the importance of keeping the children at school. The difficulty is that an equipment is needed for a short time.

To come to details, Nasset has 50 children on the roll.

If anything...
If anything in the way of an improved Day School is attempted, this school should stand first. If the Department takes up the proposal to have a joint school midway between Aiyansh and Gitladamiks, giving a midday meal I understand that the Aiyansh people will give 1 and 1/2 acres, and Gitladamiks the same on the boundary. There is a good road winter and summer. Distance from each village about one mile. As the Department has promised new school houses there should be economy in combining buildings, salaries &c.

As to Hazelton we have a splendid teacher there, Miss Soal, who also is a demoness and visits the native people in their homes. I have heard that the Methodists are pressing for a Boarding School there. The Church of England has in Hazelton and neighbourhood about 600 Indians, the Methodists none in Hazelton but in the vicinity (10 miles north and 10 miles south) about 270, the Salvation Army a few dozen, the Roman Catholics have a village 3 or 4 miles away.

Plainly the only way to have a successful Boarding School is for us all to unite upon an interdenominational school with the privilege of giving religious instruction to our own flock. So far as our Indians in Hazelton are concerned an improved day school on the line indicated would, I think, meet the need. Why should the Government take children away from their parents and clothe and feed them, when these parents live in good houses, earn good wages &c.?

As I have already pointed out travelling expenses are high, the cost of living much greater than in the East, it is necessary to offer a man and his wife a good salary to make...
to make it worth their while to go to an out of the way place and live among Indians. I earnestly trust that the Department will recognize the fact that the Day Schools cannot be made efficient on $300.00 a year. Until I know how much the salary is to be I cannot very well secure capable teachers but I shall be looking out for such.

Yours faithfully,

F.H. DuVernet,
Bishop of Caledonia.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the personal request made to you by two of the Nass Indians, who were here today, for compensation for an Indian who is said to have conducted school at Aiyansh for short periods during the years 1913-14 and 1914-15 I beg to say that the Aiyansh School was closed at the end of the March quarter, 1911. No returns have been received since then until the December quarter, 1915.

Mr. Inspector Tyson in his report on the schools in the Nass Agency for the year 1914 states as follows:

"At Aiyansh and Gitlada'micks conditions are very unsatisfactory. The new schools which were to be erected at these places have, as yet, not been built, owing to the fact that the Indians want industrial schools established in place of the ordinary day schools, and although part of the lumber and other materials have been provided for the new schools work has not been commenced." Again, when he visited the schools with the Royal Commission, in speaking of Aiyansh he states that "visited the 9th of October. School has been conducted here by an Indian named Mercer, who..."
who receives a small remuneration from the Indian people. They are, however, very anxious to have a qualified teacher appointed and ask that if it is possible to have one sent in at once, arrangements will be made to secure a temporary school building."

Judging by Mr. Tyson's report there was no school conducted during the year 1913-14, but you will see from his second report that an Indian named Mercer had been conducting a school there and received a small remuneration from the Indians. This Indian never received any authority to open the school from the Department and no returns were sent in and the Department had no knowledge of it until Mr. Tyson's report was received in November of last year. As the school was apparently not in operation no notice was taken of this report. The Department does not know how much the Indians paid Mr. Mercer, what benefit the children received from his teaching or how long he conducted the school and the only way to find out would be to obtain a report from Mr. Agent Perry.

We have no reports from either the Agent or the School Inspector regarding this school since it was closed. Rev. Mr. Green, late School Inspector, visited Aiyansh in May, 1912, in company with Agent Perry, and found the school closed and he recommended that it be not re-opened until there was a proper understanding with the Indians in regard...
regard to school matters and until the church authorities obtained a qualified and suitable teacher approved by the Department.

Nothing was done about re-opening the school until late last fall, when Miss Vera A. Chasteney was appointed teacher. The school was again opened at the end of December, last.

The Acting Deputy Superintendent General,

Regarding the dismissal of Miss Chasteney, teacher of the Aiyansh Indian School, Nass River, by Mr. Inspector Tyson, as stated in her letter of the 5th instant, I beg to say that this is the first intimation the Department has received that Miss Chasteney's services have been dispensed with and there is nothing on file to show that Mr. Tyson consulted the Department before dismissing her.

The school was opened in December, last, and the only reports received are two from Mr. Agent Perry for the months of April and May, last. In the April report he states that the school is being conducted with apparently satisfactory results. There is nothing to show, however, that he visited the school since it has been opened. In the May report he states that the children are all leaving for the canneries at Port Nelson and that Miss Chasteney is taking her holidays during the months of July and August, as he had been unable to arrange with the cannery management to have a summer school there.

In this report he calls attention to the friction which...
which exists between the field matron and the two young teachers. He says that Miss Royds, the field matron, is doing well at Aiyansh and her work is fully appreciated by the Indians. It has been reported to him that the school is often closed when it should be open. The teacher and matron are living apart and there is no co-operation that would have a tendency to make the work of the school effective. He thinks that the trouble lies in the fact that the teacher, who is young and just from the Normal School, together with Miss Bowen, who is also a young girl straight from Normal School, looked to Miss Royds to do all the housework cooking, etc., and were unwilling to do their share in the housework and other domestic duties. Instead of getting Indian help they quarrelled and separated. The Indians are ready to see that friction exists and the effect is not good from any point of view. He recommends the appointment of a more experienced and older person to take charge after the vacation, if one can be secured.

Possibly Mr. Inspector Tyson had received a similar report and acted on it. Apparently Miss Chasteney was not suitable for the position and the interests of the school called for the appointment of another teacher. Her
Her services practically ceased on the 30th of June and Mr. Tyson's notice of dismissal was to take effect on the 31st of July. This is giving her one month's notice, which is all that is required, while she claims that she should be paid until the end of August.

You will remember my name in connection with the Aigasht Indian School, Nas River, where I have been in charge since the opening of the school in December last. As you know, I started under great disadvantage owing to the desertion of the person who was sent up as field matron, thus leaving me the house duties as well as my school work, in the severity of a northern winter. However, I did my best and fulfilled my school duties conscientiously and I believe very successfully. I had many expressions of satisfaction and gratitude from the natives.

It was arranged by Agent Perry, Metlakatla, that I take as my holiday the months July and August. On arriving in Vancouver I was requested to call at Mr. Tyson's office, where I
was handed a notice signed by Mr. Tyson, dated July 3rd, saying that my services would not be required after July 31st, giving no reason for my dismissal. I believe under school law that I am entitled to an inspection, which I have not had, also to a full month's notice from the first of the month. I therefore consider that I am entitled to my salary until the end of August and above all a reason for my dismissal, if this crude notice is official.

I have been unable to send in my report for the June quarter, having no report forms, for which I have asked Agent Perry repeatedly during the past seven weeks. I understand that the forms are essential to acceptance.

My cheque for the March quarter, which I received late in June in spite of the fact that they left August promptly at the close of the quarter, did not include the Physical Drill Bonus to which I am entitled under Strathcona Trust. This also I have mentioned to Mr. Perry.
but have received no reply whatever, either to this or to my request for report forms.

I am sorry to trouble you personally with this but will you kindly take the matter up and see what can be done. I feel particularly hurt and discouraged at such neglect and bad treatment after putting my best efforts against such odds into my school work, single handed, with forty-eight pupils.

Trusting you will give this your immediate attention,

Yours truly,
Vera A. Chasteney.
Ottawa, July 17, 1916.

Sir:

I have the honor to report that when I was on the Naas River inspecting the Schools, the Chiefs from the Kitlaedamax Reserve requested me to attend a meeting of the people in their village in regard to a school for their children.

I reached Kitlaedamax at 2:30 P.M. The Chiefs were gathered in Mr. Smith's house and I listened to them for two hours. They referred to the letters and petition they had sent in some months ago praying for a school for their children. They explained that in past years they had opposed schools and wished to be left to their old way of living. But that two years ago Mr. Superintendent Vowell and Mr. Indian Agent Morrow visited them and advised them to give up the Potlatch, Indian Dances, Whiskey making and all the old Heathen customs; that they accepted the advice, gave up those practices and settled down to civilized life.

They also stated that the Superintendent and the Agent assured them that if they would do so, the Department would help them, and furnish the Government row to give them a school for their children, and they desire a white teacher to be engaged by, and under the control of the Department. I found that there were only two children of school age in the village. I never saw them anxious for a school. They said they would give the Department use for a School House for the present if a teacher was engaged, and that whenever the Department should consent for a school, they would give all the work and make a good job of it, if the Department would furnish the material.

There are young progressive men and I am sure they mean well.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No. 343016, dated Feb 5th, in which you say that the Department will be glad to hear from me in regard to several matters relating to Indian Schools.

Will you allow me to say first of all that the Government's long delay in giving a decided answer to the Indians in regard to the land Question is having a most disastrous effect upon our educational and religious work among the Indians. Our Church of England missionaries in this Diocese of Caledonia (Northern B.C.) have steadily counselled the Indians to be law abiding. In consequence of this the Indians say that we are servants of the Government trying to get their land from them. Our Indians have been stirred up by agitators. They have been asked to raise a large sum of money to carry their case to the Privy Council. Money is being freely given for this purpose. Our Missionaries hold aloof from this telling the Indians that if they will only wait patiently the Dominion Government will see that they are treated fairly. Not very long ago Indian Delegates from all parts assembled at Vancouver to arrange to carry their claims to England. I think the Department should inquire who presided at this meeting. I am informed that it was an official of the Indian Department. Since then the attitude of our Indians towards our Missionaries is more marked. Our missionaries are loyal to those in authority while at the same time telling the Indians what will be best for them in the end.
To give a specific example of what I mean:

Our Massett Indians were not in the least agitated about the land question, they were quite contented in mind until they received a letter from Rev. Mr. Tait a Methodist Missionary more than 500 miles away. He and the Rev. A.R. Green seem to be the chief movers in this matter. Rev. A.R. O'Meara, Church of England, does not belong to this Diocese, and has no authority from me. No doubt some of our missionaries think that the question of the Indian Title should be authoritatively settled but as a Body we hold that the Indians being wards of the Dominion Government, this Government should have the question settled without this most unwise stirring up of the Indian mind. This is by way of introduction to what I have to report.

1. With great difficulty and at much expense I secured a male teacher for Gitladamika, the uppermost Indian village on the Nass river. Mr. R.J. George has an expert knowledge of gardening and farming & has an earnest desire to show the Indians of this village how to cultivate their rich lands. Accompanied by Archdeacon Collison, who knows the language well, I took him up the river last summer and introduced him assuring the people that he was not after their land, but only wished to teach them and do them good. They received him most kindly until the delegate from this land conference returned from Vancouver. Now Mr. George writes me as follows:—"At a Council meeting at Gitladamika to consider the matter of setting apart a piece of land for the Mission house they were so undecided that they came to no decision. I inquired the cause and was told they considered me the thin end of the wedge. They summed up the situation thus. The Bishop, the Archdeacon, Mr. McCullagh and myself are the servants of the Government and are seeking to deprive them of their land. Seeing that I am regarded as a traitor by them..."
I have concluded after prayerful consideration that the only thing for me to do is to leave the river.

Mr. A. R. Smeath, our School teacher at Lakkalzap on the same river, writes by the same mail in much the same strain. I shall endeavour to persuade these men to hold on, but you will see how this land agitation is upsetting all our work. The feeling up the Skeena has been intense but is a little easier now. Our Missionaries urged the Indians to wait patiently till the Commissioner came from Ottawa. He came but only to repeat the same message which had so often been given before—"I will report to Ottawa all you have to say". The Indians have great respect for authority. All that is needed is a decided answer.

2. In regard to Massett a new industry has developed at North Island a fishing Company is erecting a station there with a steamer carrying fish to Prince Rupert. In consequence of this large numbers of the Massett people have gone from the Village. What Rev. Mr. Hogan recommends is that Miss Edenshaw should continue teaching the little ones at Massett and that Mr. Sherwood should follow the bigger children to North Island and teach school there. If the Department will make a grant of rough lumber 3,000 ft at $17.50 per thousand, with shingles &c the natives will put up 30 x 20 with a "Lean-to" at back for teacher to live in.

I wrote about this to the Indian Agent, Queen Charlotte Islands, but as Mr. Perry was leaving about that time the letter may be waiting for the new agent, whoever he may be to arrive. I hope the department will make this small grant. It will be seen from this that owing to this new move on the part of so many of the people the question of tents must be deferred for another year. This will show the Department what we have to contend with in trying to carry out any plan.

3. I asked Mr. Fuller the Carpenter to whom I referred to in my previous letter if he would undertake the work of teaching the Indian young men & older boys carpentry but he sees too good an
opportunity for work in Prince Rupert to accept such a position. I think that this is a matter which the Indian Agent should take in hand.

Let me say in closing that I fully appreciate the difficulty in connection with the Indian Title and the dispute between the two Governments but there is no denying the fact that our whole Indian work is suffering because of the lack of a decisive answer from those who represent "The King."

I remain

Yours faithfully

(sgd) F. H. Du Vernet
Bishop of Caledonia

REPORT ON KITLAKDAMOX VILLAGE MATTERS, NAAS AGENCY.

I have the honor to report that on May 2nd, I visited the Indian village of Kitlakdamox with Mr. Indian Agent Perry. Many of the Indians were away, but I saw those that were here, including the head Chief. I enquired of them the reason of their objection to the erection of the school house in their village by the builder who was under instructions from the Department and who had a lot of material on hand; after, they, the Indians, had for years asked for such a building. They said that they wished to have a school, and to have their children taught, but that the Rev. Mr. McCullough of Aiyansh had told them it would not be wise to have a day school, but to wait a little and then they would have a large boarding school, or an industrial school, halfway between the villages of Kitlakdamox and Aiyansh, where the children would be fed and clothed by the Government.

I would respectfully recommend that no further steps be taken re school in this village until the Indians are in a more settled condition.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR R.H. CAIRNS ON THE METLAKATLA SCHL.

I met Mr. Perry and discussed with him the educational problems of his agency.

There is a village on the Nass River called Aiyansh which has a large number of children of school age but for several years there has been no school.

The Royal Commission visited the Nass Agency in October going up the Nass river in gasoline launches.

It is Mr. Perry's opinion that something could, perhaps, be done for these people after his visit. It appears that for some time these people have refused to have a school erected in their village. However, I met some of these people at Prince Rupert and had conversation with them. From the tone of their conversation I think these people are prepared to be sane and reasonable.

We also discussed the subject of trained teachers. The greatest factors in any educational system is the teachers. I would, therefore, recommend that vigorous effort be made to have trained teachers appointed to fill any vacancies that may occur.
I have the honor to acknowledge of your telegram of October 28th which reached me on my return from the villages of the Nass River, whither I had been on a lecture trip with the lantern, dealing with the subject of tuberculosis etc. I got back on the night of the 2nd.

I proceeded to Prince Rupert yesterday—the 3rd—to consult with His Lordship Bishop Du Vernet relative to the appointment of teachers and a Field Matron. I found that the Bishop was in the Peace River country, a great distance from communication, and that is was not known when he would return.

Having in mind that the Nass River might freeze over at any time, and that it is necessary to act quickly, I wired to Inspector Tyson, Vancouver, asking him to kindly interview Mr. Cairns, Inspector of Schools and arrange suitable appointments, subject, of course, to your approval. I knew of no suitable persons in the north.

I am not sure if you are aware of the resolution of the Anglican Synod here made some time ago, the burden of which was a decision to discontinue the nomination of teachers for the schools of the Anglican Mission villages, and leaving such nominations absolutely

Sir:

In accordance with your wish as expressed in a letter to me from Prince Rupert in July, three teachers have been sent to take charge of the Indian Day Schools at Gwinoha, Aiyansh, and Gitlakdamiks.

All three are trained and experienced teachers and will, I am convinced, give faithful and efficient service.

He showed a marked interest in his pupils and was very kind and patient with the Indian children. He also cultivated a small garden and in this added a new interest in the lives of the pupils. Mr. and Mrs. R. R. Johnson have gone to Aiyansh. Both are teachers. Mr. Johnson was trained as a teacher in Ireland where he taught two years before coming to Canada. He has been in Canada six years and for five years was in charge of the Mail Order Department in Woodward's store, Vancouver. He supplied for a few months in British Columbia Schools. He is thirty years of age. Mrs. Johnson was also trained and taught six years with success. She is a musician both vocal and instrumental. They will give faithful service. Miss Lydia Hayes who is twenty-four years of age has gone to Gitlakdamiks. She has had a full course of training in the Normal at Vancouver. She has taught two and one half years in a rural school. I have not much to say about this place except to remark that after the flood of Nov. 1917, the so-called school and teacher's "lodging-house" is no longer fit for habitation and are to be demolished in July this year.

The whole village is moving to Kitladamicks, so that a new school is expected by the Indians. What will happen is unknown to me. The only way to make progress up here is to have a nice new school building where a teacher can enforce all the usual school laws etc. The children and people are far behind those of the other reserves on this River owing to their want of education. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your favour #299590-1, dated June 6, in reply to mine of April 15 last, recommending that a teacher be secured to take charge of the Gitlakdamiks Indian Day school for the full teaching months of the year. I am afraid the salary viz., $750.00 per annum with legal bonus, which is offered by the Department would not be sufficient inducement for a teacher with proper qualifications to take the position, especially when it is known that the school teacher at Lakgalzap, an Indian village on the Nass River more conveniently situated - is receiving a salary of $900.00 per annum with bonus and allowances for fuel and light. It has always been most difficult to obtain teachers for the Indian Day schools of the Upper Nass River chiefly on account of the trying isolation, and the difficulty and expense of reaching these out of the way Indian villages.

Gitlakdamiks is about 60 miles from the nearest point of steamer call, which is Mill Bay, wharfery at the mouth of the Nass River. The Mill Bay conveyance to Gitlakdamiks is consequently has to be made by Indian canoe or boat. Under these circumstances, I would suggest that the same salary and allowances be granted for a teacher at Gitlakdamiks as is allowed for the teacher at Lakgalzap. It has been my constant endeavour to follow the strictest economy in all matters where any expenditure is involved, but judging from past experience in connection with securing teachers for the Upper Nass River, I feel sure it would be most difficult to secure the services of a qualified teacher for Gitlakdamiks unless sufficient inducement can be offered.

Trusting the Department may give this matter further consideration,

I remain,

I do not believe that any great success can be attained by this school till we have a trained teacher working in a properly designed schoolroom quite separate from the Anglican Mission. This present plan of having an untrained missionary attempt to teach the school, as well as do his other missionary work is very unsatisfactory.

The teacher reports to me that the parents are indifferent with regard to the school. This is certainly not true. The parents spoke to me individually and the leaders spoke in a Council Meeting requesting that they be given a proper school and a trained teacher. This has, I understand, been reported on by Mr. Collison, the Indian Agent, who was with me throughout my inspection and, of course, at the Council Meeting in the evening when the affairs of the School - Day and Residential - took up several hours, and at which I spoke at some length.

The attendance at this Day School is poor and irregular BECAUSE IT IS NOT WORTH WHILE FOR THE CHILDREN TO ATTEND. The teaching for years has evidently been so bad that the better educated Indians are simply disgusted with the school. I can see no reason why any Indian would want to send his child to this very unattractive room in the Mission House, where the so called teaching is more or less hopeless. These people are, in my opinion, in the right and are certainly entitled to a proper school taught by a CERTIFICATED TEACHER.

I have the honour to again inform the Department that no great success can be attained in the education of the Indian children of this village till we have a trained teacher working in a properly designed schoolroom. It was made clear to me that the Indian people wish for proper education for their children and that they are very anxious to have a school building located in their village. They are perfectly ready to have the children attend regularly if they are given a teacher who knows how to teach, and who would be able to take a lead in the activities of the young people of the village.

The present plan of having an untrained missionary attempt to teach the school as well as to do his other missionary work continues to be most unsatisfactory. I should have recommended a change of teachers long ago, had there been any place for a trained teacher to carry on a school. The building of a proper school house with a small teacher's residence is a matter of the utmost importance to the life of this Indian community.

Mr. Collison is, I know, in agreement with my views on the situation and has, no doubt, reported to the Department with regard to the clearly expressed wishes of the Indians.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR BARRY
HIS INSPECTION OF THE GITLADAMICKS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.
** DATE OF INSPECTION MAY 5, 1936.

Name of teacher: Rev. S. Kinley.

The Reverend S. Kinley is the local Anglican Missionary. He has had no Normal Training whatever. In 1934 he attended the summer school in Victoria and received the usual Provincial certificates in Primary Work as well as the usual Provincial certificates in Rural and Indian Problems. His Summer School work helped him during the following year. I have done my best to indicate and demonstrate the best methods to be followed in teaching these Indians' children but the result of all the effort expended here has been very disappointing in that very poor progress is being made by the pupils.

The Missionary is of course doing his best to instruct the children, as well as to carry on the other duties that fall to his lot, Missionary Work, care of the sick, Etc. Owing partly to his lack of professional training, but more to his natural lack of teaching ability, he simply is not able to get worth while results in this school.

In addition to again demonstrating methods and indicating the extent of work to be covered in each Grade and Sub Grade, I particularly asked the Missionary to be much stricter with the children, particularly the small girls, whose conduct in school leaves much to be desired. On several occasions during my tour up the Coast the Indians from this village complained to me that the children are permitted to play in school, talk when they should be working, and even carry on heated discussions on such subjects as witchcraft, making accusations against each other, and being carried on by many of the families of other children. All this above, I am informed, takes place in Indian and without the knowledge of the teacher, who appears to the Indians to be quite unable to control the children. I instructed the teacher to punish the children if necessary, but to get control in any case, and I informed him that the Indians were complaining, though he knew this as they had spoken to him also about the lack of discipline. The Indians like the Rev. S. Kinley as a Missionary but ask for a trained teacher in his place.

I would strongly recommend that as soon as possible a proper school be built in this village, and a trained teacher appointed who is also a trained nurse. Such Anglican teacher-nurses are available. A male teacher who had been trained at a Normal School and who had successful Provincial experience in some Province, with a wife who was a trained nurse, would also be suitable in this out-of-the-way village. I know that Doctor McQuarrie would like some one here who had regular training as a nurse, and I told him so, recommending a teacher-nurse in my report on the Gitladamicks School. Such a person could no doubt live with the Missionary and his wife in the Mission House. In any case the need for a proper Indian day school to accommodate at least forty children is urgent, and I hope that the Department will give favourable consideration to my recommendation.

The Indians are quite well aware that the teacher is neither able to control their children or to teach them. They do not trouble to see that the pupils attend regularly. In fact the attendance is highly irregular. The Register, which is well kept shows that many children only attend for half a day, and even that is not regular. The percentage attendance would appear to be well below 50% in the winter quarters and far less in the summer time when many of the people are probably out of the village.

GITLAKDAMICKS: At the present time school is carried on in a room in the mission house under conditions which are not entirely satisfactory both as regards accommodation and location. The present teacher, Rev. S. Kinley, is not a trained teacher, and whilst he does his best to instruct the children, the school is not making the progress it should, with the result that the Indians are dissatisfied, especially as they know other villages on the river have fully trained teachers in charge of the schools.

I would strongly recommend, as I have done in previous reports, that a suitable school building be put up at the earliest opportunity, and that a fully trained teacher be appointed.

A married man would be preferable, especially if his wife were a trained nurse capable of dispensing simple drugs, and attending to the needs of the sick in the village. Being cut off completely from the outside from November to April in each year on account of the winter freeze-up, the people of Gitlakdamicks have a special plea in this regard, and the appointment of a nurse or field matron would go far in solving the problem of medical service for the Indians on the upper Nass.

My dear Bishop Rix:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you express the hope that the Department will be in a position to supply two teachers for work at the Aiyansh Indian Day School.

I note that the enrolment at the Aiyansh School for the June quarter amounted to 45 and of course the average attendance was substantially less than this. This is a rather high enrolment but scarcely one that would justify the employment of two teachers unless the average attendance from day to day amounted to approximately 45 pupils. Unless the Public School Acts have been changed recently, public schools can only qualify for the payment of grants to two teachers when the enrolment exceeds 46.

I regret to state that it was not possible to include in this year's estimates the amount necessary to provide two teachers at this school, regardless of what the enrolment might be. All Indian day schools are, as you know, operating on a nine month rather than a ten month basis and, in addition to this, we simply have been unable to secure the funds to open a number of our seasonal schools in the outlying districts. I can only express the hope that this critical and exacting period in which we find ourselves will pass quickly and thus enable us to make more adequate provision for the education of our Indian wards, particularly in the outlying sections of the Dominion.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

With reference to the vacancy at Gitlakdamix Indian Day School, I would advise that I have received an application for this position from Miss Louise Jane Brunton who is a fully qualified teacher of many years' experience and, although 60 years of age, appears to be extremely capable and is highly recommended by one of her former Inspectors, Major Manning.

Herewith quarterly report of the Agent, Bella Coola Indian Agency, also administering the Skeena River Agency, for the period ending June 30th, 1946.

EDUCATION: - Skeena River Agency schools were inspected at Fort Simpson and Kitkatla. At Simpson there should be a change of teachers this fall. At Kitkatla there should be a two room school and a detailed report on this has reached the Department. The situation at the Crosby Girls Home at Port Simpson is difficult but it is recommended that the school be re-opened next term, and a new staff appointed. Schools at Gitlakdamit, Greenville, Kincolith and Essington appear to have functioned with satisfaction. The seasonal school at Sunnyside is being kept open through the summer. The one room school at Fort Edwards will become a two room school this fall. The Great need is for a Departmental Inspector to co-ordinate and supervise the schools. Agents have not the time required to do this work in a worthwhile manner.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Reference your 12-11-2 of December 30th.

Enclosed please find the following documents:

(a) Non-professional Certificate (Third Class) for Miss Lucy Leflar issued by the Advisory Board, Department of Education, Province of Manitoba. Certificate dated September 15, 1911.

(b) Third Class Teaching Certificate issued by Department of Education, Province of Saskatchewan to Miss L. Leflar. Certificate dated March 1, 1912 and expired on June 30, 1913.

(c) Marriage License for Miss Leflar to Sydney Wishart dated August, 1913.

In other words, Mrs. Wishart holds a Third Class Non-professional Certificate (not a license to teach) from the Province of Manitoba and a Third Class Certificate from the Province of Saskatchewan which expired some thirty-four years ago. It is also noted that she was given a temporary British Columbia Certificate which was extended to June 30, 1946.
If you will refer to article No. 47 of the April issue of the Bulletin, you will find that clause nine reads as follows:

"Teachers holding Third Class Certificates, Teaching permits and similar licences based upon short teacher training courses and incomplete high school academic standing will be classified as Grade 1 Teachers only". This means that Mrs. Wishart would normally be entitled to a maximum salary of $112.00 a teaching month. However, the salary schedule also provides "that no teacher in 1947-48 and thereafter, shall while holding the same position held in 1946-47, receive a lower salary than the total amount paid him in 1946-47". As Mrs. Wishart was receiving $131.00 a teaching month previous to the inauguration of the salary schedule, the Department has continued to pay her at this rate and she is not entitled to any increase in salary until she produces evidence of holding a higher class of teaching certificate.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Gitlakdamix Indian Day School

As you are aware, Miss Sarah Freeman and Miss Martha L. Nichols have been appointed as teacher at the above mentioned school. I am in receipt of advice from Supt. Anfield that the Nass River is presently completely impassible and it will be necessary for these teachers to be flown in to Aiyansh from Terrace, B.C. A plane has to be chartered for this purpose as there is no other method of transportation at this time and Mr. Anfield has requested that, if possible, the Department pay some portion of this cost. As the usual boat transportation is not available I feel that consideration should be given to this request and would recommend that the teachers be required to pay half the plane charter, the Department to pay the other half. I have today written to Mr. Anfield asking him to advise what the fare will amount to and will forward this information on to you when received.

Miss Nichols left Vancouver last Wednesday to connect with the plane chartered by Supt. Anfield. However, just prior to her departure a wire was received from Mr. Anfield advising that due to icy conditions the plane would be unable to land at Aiyansh. We were unable to contact Miss Nichols in time to prevent her sailing and she is now at Prince Rupert awaiting improvement in weather conditions. Under the circumstances and as the delay is something over which Miss Nichols has no control, I would recommend that salary be paid her as from February 5th, the date on which she arrived in Prince Rupert.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, July 23rd, 1931.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the June quarter return of the Gitlädamiiks Indian Day School.

It is noted that this return is signed by Rev. Samuel Kinley and states that he took charge of the school on May 13th. In preparing the return, he states that the school was open for thirty-three (33) days during the quarter and it would, therefore, appear that the return that has been forwarded only covers the period during which Rev. Mr. Kinley has been in charge of the school. As you will note from official letter of April 10th, last, the Department understood that Rev. Mr. Flores would continue in charge at Gitlädamiiks until June 1st, on which date he would be succeeded by Rev. Mr. Kinley.

Please let me know for what length of time Rev. Mr. Flores conducted the Gitlädamiiks School during the June quarter in order that the amount due both Mr. Flores and Mr. Kinley may be paid. If Mr. Flores was in charge until the date Mr. Kinley apparently arrived, it would appear that the fairest way to divide the salary would be to pay one and a half months to each. No payment will be made, however, until your reply is received.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to refer Your Lordship to previous correspondence in connection with the erection of a new school building for the Kitladaanax Indian reserve. The Department has lately heard with much regret of the destruction of the building on the Algonkian reserve and it is thought that this might be an opportune time to again give careful consideration to the question of a union school for these two villages. A building which could be erected on the boundary between the two reserves would only be one mile from each of the villages. My dear Mr. Perry,—The Indians here and at Gitlakdamiks had an united meeting yesterday for the purpose of discussing the school question, particularly as regards the erection of the school buildings now about to be put up at Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks. A deputation from the meeting waited upon me afterward with a request that I write to you immediately as follows:—

1. The Indians unitedly ask that no buildings shall be erected until after their claims for an entire and final settlement be heard and adjusted. They set forth that the continual reception of Government financial assistance is inconsistent with the position they have taken up at the present time, and that such a course on their part is likely to prejudice their case or obscure the issue in its final consideration.

2. They have definite ideas regarding education and look forward to the acquisition of special facilities in this regard when a final settlement is made with them regarding their land &c. They claim that the government day school does not meet their requirements and does not produce results commensurate with the expenditure involved. They assert that the two villages being only two miles apart it would be more efficient if a common school were built on the boundary line between the two villages, and the separate school grants now made devoted to the payment of a duly qualified teacher.

3. They request that if it is too late now to stop the work, that the material for the separate schools now assembled and awaiting transportation up river be incorporated into one building on the boundary line. But they would deem it a special favour from the Department if the whole thing were held in abeyance for a time.

The canoe is starting immediately and this is all I am able to say at present.

Yours sincerely,

September 21st, 1911.

I have the honor to inclose you herewith a copy of a letter received today from the Rev. J.B. Mc Cullagh, missionary to the Indians at Aiyansh, Nass River, in relation to the schools proposed to be erected on the Nass River.

The school at Lek-kalnap is now being erected, and it was my intention to proceed with the Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks schools immediately upon the completion of the former school, but for reasons assigned in the letter the Indians are stated to require the cessation of the work pending the final settlement of their land grievances by the Imperial authorities.

I would remind the Department that in September of last year I met the Indians both at Aiyansh and at Gitlakdamiks to discuss the school situation. At that time they protested strongly against the idea of a joint school, and were delighted at the prospect of having separate schools.

While on the Nass River in June last taking the Indian Census I discussed the matter fully with the Rev. Dr. Mc Cullagh, and afterwards selected the site for the new building in the village of Aiyansh, while the same site had been decided upon before. Mr. Mc Cullagh was pleased with this arrangement.

Since that time, however, the matter appears to have been reconsidered, and the Indians, through Mr. Mc Cullagh, request that the matter of building be held in abeyance.

The idea that the Indians have definite ideas of education etc., seems to be absurd, to say the least. They do not know their own minds. At the same time I can understand the discontent of the Indians in the matter of the Day school at

Aiyansh. They have never had a proper building to hold school in, therefore they do not know anything about a properly conducted and equipped school.

I would further state that, since the adjustment of their land grievances has been deferred pending the conclusion of the Coronation function, and further held over until after the general election (as they have been told) the Indians have taken for granted that the Government is trying to shuffle the issue, and they do not want any concessions or favours from the Government until this—the business of all businesses with them—has been settled.

The Department will know that in April of this year the Naze Indians were offered a gift of new lumber in order to replace old and unsanitary camping shacks at Fishery Bay, and they refused to consider the matter on the grounds of their impression that the Government only wanted to put them up new houses so that it could afterwards claim a right to the land on which the houses stood.
