October 28th, 1911.

C.C. Perry, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Metlakatla, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I have carried out your instructions in connection with the Nass River schools, and have closed all school work.

The school at Lak-kalzap is complete, and ready for use. The materials for Aiyansh and Gitlakadnike schools already sent up river are stored at Aiyansh, as the people at Gitlakadnike objected to the landing of school materials at their village, the chief objector being Jimmy Woods I understand.

The materials are in charge of John Davis, of Aiyansh; the remainder of the materials are stored at Lak-kalzap, in charge of Samuel Mc Kay, the destroyed material is stored in his house, and the lumber under the canvas cover in safe protection from the weather.

I have forwarded to you all receipts, in duplicate, hoping they have reached you safely.

You can understand that this work on the river has caused me to advance quite an amount of money on behalf of the Department to enable the work to be carried through thus far successfully, and that I have given up my contract work for the best six months in the year to be able to carry this school work to a satisfactory conclusion, and now the work has been stopped my position is one I think, which entitles me to some compensation for the loss of at least six month's wages. I should be much obliged if you will lay my case before the Department, pointing out that I have given up my work elsewhere to carry out the Nass work; and now that it has closed so soon I stand at a considerable loss. It can easily be understood that I, a contractor, could not afford to give up my contract work to go up the Nass for a period of only two months on a wage of only five dollars per day.

The work I was engaged to carry out was at least six months' work, so I ask that, as compensation, the Department pay me for two month's work at the rate of five dollars per day, making a sum of $250.

I will be much obliged if an early settlement of the accounts already in could be made, as the delay will cause me further loss, and hamper my endeavour to make good the loss I must suffer under the circumstances of this alteration of arrangements.

I am, Sir,

Yours truly,

J.H. Wiseman.

Sir:

I have conferred with Archdeacon Collison with whom I arrived at Kincolith last night, on the matter of coming to Lak-kalzep, to see the school and wind up the work of school construction for the present year.

I am informed that the Indians are engaging in a big potlatch tomorrow, preparations for which are in progress today. In consequence I do not deem it advisable to visit Lak-kalzep just now, as it would be impossible to arrange a meeting of the Indians, and my presence at Lak-kalzep just now would belittle my influence, the Indians being quite likely to suspect that I was there to watch their movements. I thought of sending you a letter by specially chartered launch today, but an second thought that the Indians might suppose that by this message that I had deputed your agency to act as spies or special constables, and decide to send it by Archdeacon Collison at the best and earliest opportunity.

I beg to request that you will kindly see that the materials on hand for the construction of the Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks schools are carefully stored and in charge of safe parties. I would suggest that the materials now on the bank near Gitlakdamiks, as also that at Lak-kalzep, be covered securely with a lumber covering where it stands to protect it during the winter.

Alfred Mc Kay could be asked to keep an eye on the goods at Lak-kalzep and James Smythe these at Git-lak-damiks, or other reliable men. You could tell these men that, when the materials are removed, the Government will give them five dollars apiece for their trouble.

To save the nails, etc., from getting rusty these could be taken to the homes of Mc Kay and Smythe another reliable men.

I shall also thank you to find out and report to me the names of the Indian who ordered the materials not to be landed at Gitlakdamiks or Aiyansh, and the names of the men engaged to convey the materials to these points.

I would suggest that you make no reference to schools to the Indians, and that you pack up and leave the river as soon as things are in order as above.

Your accounts could be forwarded to me for payment, and I could see you at Prince Rupert on your way down.

Very truly yours,

Charles Clifton Perry,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I am very much put out with the statement that the Department is not willing to allow for provisions while our work was in progress at the Lek-kalzep school buildings.

It will be remembered that our original arrangement with the Department through you was to supply all materials for this school, in return for which patronage the firm was prepared to undertake the personal supervision of the building, the foreman (myself) to receive wages at the rate of five dollars per day as a working unit.

It was then thought that the system prevailing with the Provincial Government of providing provisions where work was in progress beyond the reaches of ordinary civilization would apply in this case, and it was with this in view that the firm undertook the work for the Indian Department, although this was not expressly stipulated at the time of making the arrangement.

Nor was it stipulated that the firm should advance from its own funds the wages due to the workers; but this was done voluntarily to expedite the work, and should not be overlooked by the Department.

It is thought that the least the Department can do is to kindly reconsider this matter, and consent to the payment of the extra 50 cents per day during the time work was in progress at Lek-kalzep.

I beg to remain, Sir,

Yours truly,

J.W. Wiseman.

Extract from Report of the Schools in the Neas Agency by Inspector A. M. Tyson with the Royal Commission on Indian Affairs, October 19, 1915. Original on file 427021-61

The school buildings of the Neas Agency are for the most part good substantial structures and kept in excellent condition both inside and out. They are well supplied with the necessary furnishings and other school equipment. The children appear to be bright and healthy and clean and comfortably clothed. Their progress in the different lines of work is for the most part satisfactory.

The different villages of this agency all brought before the Royal Commission the question of the establishing of Industrial schools somewhere in the Neas. At each village where the meetings were held, they offered to give a site for the establishment of such an institution wherever the Department might select.

At Aiyansh, Gitladamike and Gwinahs they are most anxious to have day schools established. In the past the Indians of these villages have opposed this on the grounds that they would not have the schools established until the land question had been settled, but as the Commissioners informed them that the establishment of the schools would in no way affect their aboriginal title, and as the Land Committee has apparently failed, these Indians are now desirous that schools be established as soon as possible. They seem to realize that the education of their children is a step in the right direction. I would respectfully suggest to the Department that teachers be appointed to these villages as soon as practicable.

Sgd. A.M.Tyson. Insp.

Port Simpson, Sept. 15.—Prospectors who arrived here from the upper waters of the Nass river brought news that the Aiyansh Mission, sixty miles up the Nass, was totally destroyed by fire. According to the report a pioneer missionary, Rev. McCullough, and his family, had been left destitute.

With their reports of the occurrence are meager, it was stated that the fires started from a spark from the chimney. The roof caught fire and the wooden building was soon blazing fiercely.

It had gained great headway before it was discovered and although an alarm was sent out to the neighboring Indian villages and the vicar made every effort, the building was consumed with all its contents, including the supplies and the clothing of the missionary and his family. Referring to your letter No 67,340-5, dated Oct 20th ult., re the matter of a school for the villages of Aiyansh and Gitlakdamiks, I have the honor to state that I have recently returned from these settlements, where I examined the ground proposed to be covered if a joint school were erected.

I would point out that the matter of a joint school has been a bone of contention since the last visit of Mr Supt Vowell to Gitlakdamiks and Aiyansh, when the Indians were at both places, promised a separate school. Mr Inspector has also told the Indians (so they tell me) that the Department would likely build two schools; and it would appear that both Mr Vowell and Mr Green went so far as to look into the matter of a site at both places.

If it were decided by the Department to erect a joint school between the two villages which are about one and a half to two miles apart it would be necessary for the scholars to walk over deep snow the half distance throughout a long and bitter winter, and in my opinion the school would be very poorly attended.

It is evident that both Mr Vowell and Mr Green felt that separate schools would be best, at the same time they may not have taken into consideration the difficulty in securing teachers for these remote settlements.

I may say that Aiyansh is one of the neatest and well ordered villages on the Nass river. It has some of the most creditably built and designed houses to be seen in the North. Sir,

In reply to your letter No 67340/5, dated 10th April, with reference to the remark contained in my letter to you on the subject of the lumber for the Schools on the Nass River, I have the honor to inform you that the sentence to which you refer in the same was/I regret, incomplete. To it should have been added "in the event of the Indians being unable to turn out the lumber." I think this will be clearer to the Department.

I would point out that the Indians here will not under any circumstances get out timber from the woods until they are certain that the money is in hand to pay them for their labor and for the lumber. This being so it was necessary to safeguard the Department against the possibility of the Indians not being able to supply the lumber through lack of ready payment, and the item for lumber was included by the arrangement referred to in the account of the firm supplying the other material.

The wisdom of this course is now proven by the fact that when on the river with Mr Green, Inspector of schools, I found that the Indians had not even cut down a tree to be turned into lumber at their sawmill, and the arrangement with Messrs Weight & Wiseman will find the lumber supplied and shipped at sawmill prices.

Dear Sir,

Re Wars schools

In regard to purchase of materials from Wars River sawmill, I may say that I received my order back again from Mr. McCullough of Anspach stating that the mill is out of action and no lumber will be obtainable for the erection of the schools.

But as I had previously guaranteed to supply the same I have obtained the lumber elsewhere and fitted it together with all materials necessary for the three Wars school, at Prince Rupert and I agreed to do.

Everything is now in readiness to commence work as soon as the River is navigable.

With reference to the personal request made to you by two of the Nass Indians, who were here today, for compensation for an Indian who is said to have conducted school at Aiyansh for short periods during the years 1913-14 and 1914-15 I beg to say that the Aiyansh School was closed at the end of the March quarter, 1911. No returns have been received since then until the December quarter, 1915.

Mr. Inspector Tyson in his report on the schools in the Nass Agency for the year 1914 states as follows:

"At Aiyansh and Gitladamicks conditions are very unsatisfactory. The new schools which were to be erected at these places have, as yet, not been built, owing to the fact that the Indians want industrial schools established in place of the ordinary day schools, and although part of the lumber and other materials have been provided for the new schools work has not been commenced." Again, when he visited the schools with the Royal Commission, in speaking of Aiyansh he states that "Visited the 9th of October. School has been conducted here by an Indian named Mercer, who..."
who receives a small remuneration from the Indian people. They are, however, very anxious to have a qualified teacher appointed and ask that if it is possible to have one sent in at once, arrangements will be made to secure a temporary school building."

Judging by Mr. Tyson's report there was no school conducted during the year 1913-14, but you will see from his second report that an Indian named Mercer had been conducting a school there and received a small remuneration from the Indians. This Indian never received any authority to open the school from the Department and no returns were sent in and the Department had no knowledge of it until Mr. Tyson's report was received in November of last year. As the school was apparently not in operation no notice was taken of this report. The Department does not know how much the Indians paid Mr. Mercer, what benefit the children received from his teaching or how long he conducted the school and the only way to find out would be to obtain a report from Mr. Agent Perry.

We have no reports from either the Agent or the School Inspector regarding this school since it was closed. Rev. Mr. Green, late School Inspector, visited Aiyansh in May, 1912, in company with Agent Perry, and found the school closed and he recommended that it be not re-opened until there was a proper understanding with the Indians in regard
regard to school matters and until the church authorities obtained a qualified and suitable teacher approved by the Department.

Nothing was done about re-opening the school until late last fall, when Miss Vera A. Chasteney was appointed teacher. The school was again opened at the end of December, last.

Dear Sir,

I received your letter last night. I'm sorry there is any trouble about my stay in Prince Rupert. I had no wish to get off the boat (after sitting up until one o'clock in the morning) and go out into the black night in the pouring rain at Prince Rupert. But my last directions, when leaving Vancouver were, "If Mr. and Mrs. Johnston do not meet the boat at Prince Rupert, get off and wait for them." That's what I did; there were many things I was not aware of one was, that every boat doesn't call at Mill Bay.

I intended asking Mr. Cairns quite a number of questions the night I sailed from Vancouver, but he sent a message...
saying that he couldn't come. So I had to be satisfied with Mr. Douglas' answer. Then, to my dismay, I found out the next morning that Mr. and Mrs. Johnston had gone on to the Naas, and there was no chance of me getting there for another week.

Then that boat came in to Prince Rupert late and had to return to Vancouver for repairs. And I had to waste more time in Prince Rupert.

I admit that it was partly my fault, but we all make mistakes once in awhile.

If the department considers the disadvantage we must put up with, and the many unexpected expenses to living up there, on a very ordinary salary, it will pay my expenses at Prince Rupert.

I am making the best of the
Surrounding conditions, and think our school work will be a success if our supplies come in time. We are beginning to think about our Xmas. I entertainment, intend having a school concert and tree with mostly presents made by pupils at school.

Yours sincerely,

Lydia Hayes.

P.S. This letter must wait here a week, as we only send mail out once in two weeks now. L.H.

Sir:

I have the honor to submit the following report for the month of October.

During our stay at Gitlakdamix, I was fully occupied with interviews and sundry matters brought to my attention. An inspection of the day school was carried out by Capt. Barry. The pupils were medically examined and vaccinated by Dr. Macdonald who was also kept busy attending to the needs of sick Indians in the village.

In the evening of the 5th inst. accompanied by Capt. Barry, I attended a public meeting. Numerous matters were brought up for discussion. A strong request was made for the construction of a proper school building, and the appointment of a qualified teacher. School is held at present in a large room in the mission house, and is taught by the Rev. S. Kinley, Anglican Missionary at the village. The room is very unsuitable as a classroom, the light conditions being bad and accommodation quite inadequate when all the pupils attend.

If funds are available, I would strongly recommend that favorable consideration be given to the request of the Indians in this matter, and that the preparation of plans and specifications for an up-to-date building be authorized at the earliest possible time. I would point out that this is the only village in the agency without a school building.

Some years ago, the Department provided a small sawmill for Gitlakdamix, and it was then understood that in the event of a school being constructed for the village, the lumber would be supplied without charge by the Indians. In view however, of present conditions and the fact that the Indians at Gitlakdamix are badly off this year, I would recommend that the building be put up as a relief undertaking at the charge of the department. I would further suggest should it be decided to provide the school, that the Indians be authorized to get logs and cut the necessary lumber this winter so that it may be well seasoned and ready for construction purposes next year.

W. E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

To the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa,

We the undersigned members of the Nishga Nation of Indians resident on the Nass River in Northern British Columbia, feel that there is a great necessity for a Residential Industrial School in this neighbourhood.

We submit the following reasons as being likely to help you to realise our position:

1. We suggest Prince Rupert as the site for the School, being the most central location in a good environment, and what is most important, near a well equipped Hospital.

2. It would provide greater opportunities for parents for visiting their children in cases of severe illness.

3. It is our greatest wish that our children should have the opportunity of attending High School, and possibly to become apprentices in the various trades of the city.

4. We submit that there would be a great reduction in travelling expenses of the children to and from School.

5. By having a central School at Prince Rupert it would enable the Klusne, Tsimshian, Haida, and Kitasoo to send their children and while we have in the past requested a School for the Nass River people, we are prepared to waive our claim to this and to have a central School in Prince Rupert.

Trusting that this Petition will have your careful consideration and assuring you of our eagerness to co-operate with the other Tribes.

Sir:

I have in previous reports, called the attention of the Department to the great need of a school building for the Gitlakdamix village on the upper Nass river.

In April 1934, a petition was forwarded from the Indians in connection with the same matter. This village, with a school enrollment of about 37 children is the only village in the agency without a proper building.

At present, school is carried on in a room in the mission house which is not large enough, or suitable for the purpose.

A sum of $3000.00 was placed in the 1934-35 Estimates, also in the 1935-36 Estimates increased to $4000.00, and I would strongly recommend that the Department authorize the construction of a suitable building at the earliest possible date.

There are other places in the agency where new schools are needed, but I consider a school for Gitlakdamix should receive first consideration.

Your obedient servant

Sir:-

I beg to transmit herewith, my report for the month of May, as follows:-

GITLAKDAMIX

At the present time school is carried on in a room in the mission house under conditions which are not entirely satisfactory both as regards accommodation and location. The present teacher, Rev. S. Kinley is not a trained teacher, and whilst he does his best to instruct the children, the school is not making the progress it should, with the result that the Indians are dissatisfied, especially as they know other villages on the river have fully trained teachers in charge of the schools.

I would strongly recommend, as I have done in previous reports, that a suitable school building be put up at the earliest opportunity, and that a fully trained teacher be appointed.

A married man would be preferable, especially if his wife were a trained nurse capable of dispensing simple drugs, and attending to the needs of the sick in the village. Being cut off completely from the outside from November to April in each year on account of the winter freeze-up, the people of Gitlakdamix have a special plea in this regard, and the appointment of a nurse or field matron would go far in solving the problem of medical service for the Indians on the upper Nass.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Dear Sir:

I am, as you will see by the letterhead, in Montreal a long way from my western Diocese and as mails are very uncertain to and from the Telegraph Creek region so that I can not well communicate with you through your agent there. I am therefore bringing the following matters directly to your attention.

In the village of Aiyansh or sometimes called Gitlakdamics, there never has been a building for an Indian Day School. A large room in the Mission House being used for this purpose. This is not as suitable as it should be, by any means; which fact is agreed to both by the Inspector of Indians Schools, the Church, and the natives themselves. The Indian Agent, Mr. W.E. Collison, agrees with this also. May I, therefore, urge your department to take this matter under advisement and I trust you will find it advisable to provide a good school for this somewhat important village in the near future.

Dear Sir:

I am forwarding herewith a letter No. 9E-11867 dated 18th June, received from Mr. Indian Agent Collison, with regard to the need for an Indian Day School building and teacher's residence at Gitikadamix, on the upper Nass.

This matter has been discussed with Inspector Barry, who states that he has strongly recommended in his reports on the present Gitikadamix Indian Day School during the past few years that a suitable school building with classroom accommodation for at least 40 children, and accommodation for a married teacher, should be erected at the earliest possible date. A teacher whose wife can dispense simple drugs and look after minor ailments would be of great advantage in this Village. The nearest Medical Officer is Dr. McDonald at Kincolith, and it is pointed out that during the winter months, boat travel is impossible as the river is blocked with ice.

Capt. Barry is further of the opinion that little or no progress can be hoped for in the way of the education of the Indian children under the present conditions. The room in the Mission House now being used as a classroom is in many ways inadequate, but the real reason for the lack of progress in this Village is the fact that the teacher, Rev. S. Kinley, the local Missionary, is entirely untrained and unsuitable for the work he is attempting to do in the classroom.

While Capt. Barry has on several occasions reported to the Department that he was not entirely satisfied with Mr. Kinley's work, and while the Department itself has suggested

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
to the Right Rev. G. Rix, Archbishop of the Diocese of Caledonia, Prince Rupert, that a change of teachers at this point would have to be made, the fact remains that, owing to the lack of a proper school building and residence for a married teacher, the actual employment of a new teacher is a most difficult matter to arrange. Inspector Barry is well aware of these facts and wishes to give any assistance he can to Mr. Hoey in the matter.

I would recommend that, as the sum of $5,000.00 was placed in the Estimates for the present fiscal year, the Department authorize the construction of a suitable combined school and residence at the earliest possible date. I wish to draw the attention of the Department to the great difficulty which would be experienced in freighting lumber and material up the Nass River from Kincolith or Mill Bay, the nearest ports of call by Union Steamships, to Gitlakdamix. The distance between Kincolith and Gitlakdamix is almost 70 miles. Small shallow-draught river boats, which are the only ones that can go upstream, have to pass through three rapids on their way to Gitlakdamix.

I am in agreement with Mr. Indian Agent Collison when he suggests that the common lumber and heavy framing required for the proposed school be sawn at the Indian Sawmill at Aiyansh, a mile or two below Gitlakdamix. If this is approved, it will be necessary to notify the Indians at an early date as they will have to obtain the necessary logs.

In conclusion, I may say that Inspector Barry considers the matter a most urgent one, and that while a building consisting of one large classroom, and accommodation for a married teacher asked for by the Indian Agent, is the present minimum, it would be far better when designing the school to allow for two good-sized classrooms, each capable of accommodating from 35 to 40 pupils. Even if the second classroom was not absolutely necessary during the first year, the Inspector points out that the room could be made use of for Vocational instruction, and further suggests that as at
present there are a number of children attending the Indian Residential Schools at Alert Bay and Cqumloetza who, in the event of the erection of a suitable school at Gitlakdamix, could be accommodated in their home Village, at great saving to the Department in the matter of per capita fees. The enlarged Day School would be from a financial point of view, the better investment.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

A Petition

We the Council, parents and people of the Gitlakadimc Band humbly petition the Government of Canada through the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources to establish an Indian Day School in our Village.

We ask for a modern school building to accommodate at least fifty children with a teacher's residence attached. We wish to have a trained teacher who has been at normal school in British Columbia and has a certificate in the province. If possible we should like a married man whose wife is a trained nurse who could look after the health of the village, particularly of the women and children, the nearest doctor being at Prince Rupert 47 miles away.

We have a small Sawmill established with the help of the Department.
of Indian Affairs a number of years ago. Since we can cut logs and thus obtain most of the lumber for our school which would cost more if built of lumber bought in from the coast, river freight costing some $30 or $40 per thousand feet. We have heard that such a school as we ask for has been recommended for several years by our Indian Agent and Inspector of Schools but that the Government of Canada could not give us a school as they were no funds for this purpose.

We have also heard that new Indian Day Schools have been built at a number of other places during the last few years. We therefore respectfully urge that we be given a suitable day school so that our children need no longer be sent hundreds of miles away.
to residential school at Alert Bay and Coghataetga. We have 53 children of school age in the village. Copies of this petition have been sent to the Honorable Minister of Mines and Resources.

Alof Hanson, Esq., M.P.,

March 2, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of February 10th regarding the proposed Indian Day School at Gitlakdamix.

This matter has been further reviewed with Inspector Barry, a copy of whose report is enclosed herewith. I have also discussed the probable costs of such a school with Mr. C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water and Power Bureau.

The school at Gitlakdamix should be along the lines of the Bella Bella Indian Day School, now in course of construction, but could be somewhat smaller. I understand the contract price of the Bella Bella Day School was $7,907. Some $1400 of this amount was provided for electric lighting and cement work.

Having these costs in mind, I doubt if we could build the same school at Gitlakdamix, with cement foundation and full basement, for $6400. I feel, however, that the building should rest on cement pillars, instead of cedar posts as suggested, or on heavy cedar posts resting on foundational cement blocks. Capt. Barry has informed me that a suitable dry sloping site is available. The use of such a site would reduce excavation costs considerably and would provide the space required for a heating plant. In such a site the length of the foundation pillars, either cement or wood, would of course be governed by the slope of the ground. The building should be heated by a good wood-burning furnace and the warm air conveyed to the various rooms of the building by asbestos covered pipes. The fire box of such a furnace should be sufficiently large to take 4-foot lengths of wood.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
A cement foundation with full basement, similar to the Bella Bella School, is of course very desirable, but I feel it is out of the question considering $6400 to be the maximum available. I should say, however, that we could build a two-room school at Gitlakdamix along the plan of the Bella Bella School utilizing to the fullest extent the lumber produced by the local Indian sawmill for $6000, leaving $400 to go towards the costs of equipment. As the Indians are very much interested in the provision of a suitable school for their children, we could count on their wholehearted co-operation, both in the production of such lumber as could be sawn at the local mill and the provision of the necessary Indian labor. It might also be possible to secure a reasonable reduction in river transportation rates on the building materials brought in from outside.

Until it will be necessary to provide a separate room for vocational training, provision for which could eventually be made in the basement, the second classroom should be used for this purpose, as the proposed school would have accommodation for about 70 pupils and the most that would be available to attend during the first two years of the school's life would not likely exceed 50.

I am inclined to agree with the Agent's suggestion that the school be built by Indian labor under the supervision of an experienced and responsible white carpenter-builder. I should like to suggest that the Architect's Branch provide a rough draft plan of the school along the lines suggested and forward same here for examination and the views of Capt. Barry and myself before the final plan is agreed upon. The suggestion of Mr. Indian Agent Collison regarding making early arrangements for the production of the rough lumber required, so that the Indians can proceed to get out the necessary logs, is approved.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:-

With reference to the proposed Indian Day School at Gitlakdamix on the Nass River, Skeena River Agency, which you have asked me to briefly report on, I may say that the provision of a cement basement is in my opinion out of the question, no matter how advantageous. The cost of transporting materials up the Nass River through three rapids makes it necessary to use as far as possible the lumber which can be prepared in the local Indian saw mill.

I agree with your observations as contained in the last paragraph of your letter 15/8/4048 of June 30th 1938 addressed to the Department. The provision of two good sized classrooms would be a great advantage. One of these could at first be mainly used for Vocational Work and Arts and Crafts. It would not be long before it was required as a classroom when the local Indians understand how much a trained teacher can do for their children.

While provision should be made for a married teacher it might be well to have at least one extra bedroom for an assistant teacher, for I feel certain that two teachers will be required within the first three years of the school's life. Mr Hoey is of course quite correct in his opinion that 50 pupils are too many for one teacher. In B.C. we try to have a second teacher when the attendance is over 35 and certainly when over 40.

A school with the above accommodation and in addition a small room for the usual "Drugs" which could be used as a dispensary, if placed on cedar post foundations leaving room in the basement for a simple Manual Training Shop lined with shiplap lumber, should not cost more in my opinion than around $5,000.00 leaving the balance available for the complete furnishing of the two classrooms with desks blackboards etc.

I do not agree with Indian Agent Collison that the plan used at Kitselas should be followed. You have I believe a plan of a good two room Provincial Day School prepared by the Provincial Architect, while the Department has lately erected two schools of the type required, one at Port Simpson and one at Bella Bella.
I agree with Mr Collison that the order for all rough lumber should be placed with the local Indians at as early a date as possible. These Indians will have to get the necessary logs to their saw mill.

While the building of schools by contract is as a rule the best method, the peculiar circumstances of this village may incline the Department to follow the Indian Agent's advice. While many of the Indians build quite well there would of course be the need for a responsible "white" carpenter builder, who could supervise and take part in the erection and remain at Gitlakdamix till the school was completed and painted. I know nothing of the man suggested by Mr Collison.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Ottawa,
February 10, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 an amount of $6400.00 was provided for a new school at Gitlakdamix.

Recently Indian Agent Collison was written for the information which is required by the Surveys & Engineering Branch before plans can be prepared. For your information I enclose a copy of his reply. I should appreciate receiving any comments that you care to make in connection with the Agent's letter. I might add that I have also read your letter of June 30 last in connection with the erection of a school at this point.

Is it possible for you to let me have an estimate of the probable cost of erecting a school at Gitlakdamix? As noted above the amount of $6400.00 is provided and under no circumstances does the Department wish this amount exceeded.

We would prefer to place a cement basement under the building and use the basement for vocational training purposes. Owing to the high freight rates it would appear that Indian Agent Collison does not consider this advisable. What is your opinion of the matter? If a basement cannot be provided possibly it would be preferable to build a two-roomed school. I do not favour a classroom large enough to accommodate 50 pupils as this number is really too large for one teacher to handle.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Jan. 10th 168-32A-5 enclosing building data form relative to the construction of the proposed day school building at Gitlakdamix on the upper Nass river.

As you may already be aware, the Indian village of Gitlakdamix is situated about 67 miles distant up the Nass river from Mill Bay Cannery which is the nearest point of steamer call. From this point freight is transported up river by Indian motor boats. The usual charge for river freight is $1.50 per lb. and for lumber from $25. to $30. per thousand feet.

Some years ago, the Department supplied the Gitlakdamix Indians with a small sawmill with a capacity of 3,000 feet per day. This mill cuts for local needs when required. From this it will be seen that the cost of transporting lumber and material from the Coast to Gitlakdamix reserve will be a heavy item in connection with the construction of the proposed school.

I would suggest if possible, all rough lumber and heavy framing might be cut at the local sawmill leaving the hardwood flooring and other dressed lumber to be shipped from the coast.

The Indians have a small planer in connection with the mill and might be able to supply the shiplap lumber required for the building, but not the siding.

In order to make this possible, it will be necessary to place the order for lumber required with the mill at Gitlakdamix at the earliest opportunity, giving quantities, dimensions etc., so that the Indians may have ample time to get out the logs and proceed with sawing, particularly as the lumber should be dried before it is
used on the work.

With a few minor changes including increased classroom accommodation for 50 pupils, I would suggest that the plan of the Kitselas day school and teacher's residence might be suitable for Gitlakdamix. The cost of river freighting being so high, I would also recommend that a cedar post foundation be put in instead of cement.

Due to the location and conditions of transportation, building by contract will probably be very expensive, and I would suggest that the work be carried out by day labor under the supervision of a responsible builder who should remain on the ground until the work is completed. In this connection I would suggest that the work be placed in the hands of Mr. J.R. Mitchell of Prince Rupert who has had considerable experience in the construction of day schools for the Department at Massett and Kitselas.

It would be advisable to employ Indians of the village, many of whom have a working knowledge of carpentry. This would give needed employment.

Owing to the distance and expense of travel, it will be impossible for me to give frequent supervision to the work as I was able to in the case of the Kitselas day school.

The data required by the Department has been supplied as far as possible in the form attached.

Yours faithfully,

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch

Ottawa.

Memorandum: Mr. Wardle

Re: Indian Day Schools.

With regard to your memorandum of the 18th ultimo, regarding the above, it is noted that the Indian Affairs Branch proposed to use the plans of the Bella Bella school for the building at Getladamix, Saskatchewan. As the Bella Bella plans were prepared for particular site conditions, namely, solid rock at two feet below grade, it is felt that these plans would not suit the site conditions at Getladamix. Plans of a similar building with normal depth foundation walls have been prepared for the Merla Indian Reserve school, and it is felt that these plans would be more applicable to building conditions in Saskatchewan. Copies of these plans will be provided for use of the Indian Affairs Branch, if so desired.

In connection with the erection of Indian Schools by Indian Agents, where authority is granted to carry on construction without plans, or where plans of other schools are used without reference to this Service, it is felt that in all cases 4" weeping tile drains should be laid around the building at the level of the wall footings. This drain should be graded at a run some distance from the building as a precaution against water infiltration through the basement walls or floor.

It is also considered advisable that in all schools erected under the same conditions that toilet accommodation should be provided for teachers, separate from that assigned to the pupils.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Jan. 10th 169-32A-5 enclosing Building Data form relative to the construction of the proposed day school building at Gitlakdamix on the upper Nass river.

As you may already be aware, the Indian village of Gitlakdamix is situated about 67 miles distant up the Nass river from Mill Bay Cannery which is the nearest port of steamer call. From this point freight is transported up river by Indian motor boats. The usual charge for river freight is $1½ per lb. and for lumber from $25. to $30. per thousand feet.

Some years ago, the Department supplied the Gitlakdamix Indians with a small sawmill with a capacity of 5,000 feet per day. This mill cuts for local needs when required. From this it will be seen that the cost of transporting lumber and material from the Coast to Gitlakdamix reserve will be a heavy item in connection with the construction of the proposed school. I would suggest if possible, all rough lumber and heavy framing might be cut at the local sawmill leaving the hardwood flooring and other dressed lumber to be shipped from the coast.

The Indians have a small planer in connection with the mill and might be able to supply the shiplap lumber required for the building, but not the siding.

In order to make this possible, it will be necessary to place the order for lumber required with the mill at Gitlakdamix at the earliest opportunity, giving quantities, dimensions etc., so that the Indians may have ample time to get out the logs and proceed with sawing, particularly as the lumber should be dried before it is
used on the work.

With a few minor changes including increased classroom accommodation for 50 pupils, I would suggest that the plan of the Kitselas day school and teacher's residence might be suitable for Gitlakdamsx. The cost of river freighting being so high, I would also recommend that a cedar post foundation be put in instead of cement.

Due to the location and conditions of transportation, building by contract will probably be very expensive, and I would suggest that the work be carried out by day labor under the supervision of a responsible builder who should remain on the ground until the work is completed. In this connection I would suggest that the work be placed in the hands of Mr. J.R. Mitchell of Prince Rupert who has had considerable experience in the construction of day schools for the Department at Massett and Kitselas.

It would be advisable to employ Indians of the village, many of whom have a working knowledge of carpentry. This would give needed employment.

Owing to the distance and expense of travel, it will be impossible for me to give frequent supervision to the work as I was able to in the case of the Kitselas day school.

The data required by the Department has been supplied as far as possible in the form attached.

Yours faithfully

The Secretary

Building Data relating to construction of proposed new day school at Glikadamix on the upper Nass, Aiyansh P. Office

Copy of copy or form ........

(Day Labour recommended)

1. Several Indians with working knowledge of carpentry available, also common labor.

One storey frame building. Classroom to accommodate 50 pupils.

Standard Equipment: combined washroom and cloakroom.

Teacher's residence including living room, bedroom, kitchen and storeroom. Attic space for extra storage purposes.

School and residence properly protected from intense cold in winter. Suggest cedar posts instead of cement for foundation, half basement for furnace accommodation.

2. Level ground; soil sandy loam, no rock. If basement provided, drain age with 4 inch tile pipe, sketch of village site attached.

3. Water obtained from wells. Water tank should be provided for fire protection.
4. Outside toilets (Pits) for school and residence.

5. Hot air furnace. Wood fuel

6. Oil lamps recommended. Small electric lighting plant in village not dependable.

7. Usual school standard equipment. Book cupboard also etc. Blackboard space to be determined when plan of classroom available.

8. Nearest shipping point Mill Bay Cannery at mouth of Nass river. Distance Mill Bay to Gitiakdamix approximately 67 miles. River transportation Mill Bay to Gitiakdamix by Indian motor boats. Recommend tenders be invited for river freighting.

Owing to location, distance and conditions or river transportation construction by contract will probably cost more. Recommend work be carried out by day labor under supervision of capable foreman builder undertaking all responsibility and authorized to employ Indian labor, and services of one white carpenter if necessary.

Indian Agent W.S. Collison

Dear Sir:

Your File 168-32A-5.
New Indian Day School, Gitlakdamix

I have to confirm the following telegram despatched to you this day:

"REFERENCE MY AIRMAIL APPLICATION SEPTEMBER THIRTEENTH FOR EIGHT HUNDRED DOLLARS TO COVER LABOR NEW SCHOOL GITLAKDAMIX (STOP) THIS SHOULD HAVE BEEN FOR EIGHTEEN HUNDRED DOLLARS (STOP) PLEASE ARRANGE TO FORWARD THIS LATTER AMOUNT AT EARLY DATE."

It is regretted that in preparing the above mentioned letter, the amount stated therein was based on the assumption that an advance of $3000 had been received from the Department for labor and payment of lumber purchased from Indians, but our records disclose that only $2000 has been received to date. An advance of $1800 will fully adjust matters and when received will make a total of $3800 advanced by the Department to meet the costs of labour and purchase of Indian lumber.

This adjustment will not affect the total cost of construction, which will be within the estimate of $6,500.

The error is regretted and I trust that it will not cause the Branch any inconvenience.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith, vouchers 9690, 9691, 9692 and 9693 in favor of various merchants amounting to $705.80 for material supplied in connection with the construction of the new Indian day school at Gitlaidanix.

The fibreweld roofing paper was used to insulate the earth from the basement wall to prevent the decay of the planks as the Indians supplied spruce instead of cedar as requested. It was difficult to secure cedar in that locality.

The Kaizen hardware supplied raw linseed oil, the kind not being specified on the tender, hence the reason for the return of the oil and the extra cost for the boiled oil. The other items were incidentals unforeseen when the tenders were called.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett

Major W.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6390, File 810-5, part 3)
Dear Sir:

The new Indian day school at Gitlakdamix was finished September 27th, and was officially opened by a public gathering on the evening of the same day.

The school was well built, and Mr. J.R. Mitchell, the foreman, managed the construction well and completed it in a satisfactory manner with good workmanship.

The complete cost including toilets and drain was $6,413.08. A complete statement will be sent in later together with a snapshot.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett

JG/JJ

J. Gillett, Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Gillett:

I have to refer to your letter of October 19th with enclosed Voucher 9738 covering account of Mitchell and Currie, Contractors, for preparation of plans, blue prints and specifications in connection with the construction of the new school at Gitlakdamix.

In this connection I beg to advise that Mr. Collison was not authorized by this Department to employ the firm of Mitchell and Currie to prepare plans and specifications. It was expected that whatever plans were necessary would be based on the plans of the Bella Bella Day School and those of Port Simpson and Kitselas which were made available to the Agent. Mr. Collison was asked to consult Mr. Mitchell, who was to be employed as foreman carpenter, vide my letter of April 12, file 15/8/8802, regarding the plan of the building.

It is recognized that plans and specifications were necessary, but a builder usually supplies such information when he tenders or is employed on proposed construction without cost to the Department. Quotations are being asked for from day to day by this office which frequently necessitate plans and specifications which require considerable time and preparation but I can recall no instance where the Department has been called upon to pay for such work. As you know, $6500 was provided for the Gitlakdamix School with instructions that under no circumstances was this amount to be exceeded. From the returns received, the actual cost is somewhere in the neighborhood of $6425, leaving a balance of $75 of the appropriation unexpended.

Any draughtsman could prepare the rough plans supplied in this case in a matter of three days at the most and the blue prints should not have cost more than $3.00 per set. The most I would be prepared to do in the matter is to recommend that the Department favorably consider providing a sum not exceeding $50.00 for the plans and specifications provided. You might therefore discuss the matter with Messrs. Mitchell and Currie, and if this arrangement would be acceptable to them, to have the accounts and vouchers amended accordingly, and please submit same to this office.

Yours faithfully,

"D.M. MacKay."

Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Your File 168-32A-5.

I have to refer to your letter of February 13 regarding furnishings for the teacher's quarters of the new Indian Day School at Gitlakdamix.

I may say that it is hoped to obtain a married teacher for this school for the academic year 1940-41, whose wife might look after the health work among the Indians of the local village, but as there are few if any qualified teachers available in British Columbia at the present time and that it is now too late to send a teacher to Gitlakdamix before the end of the current school year, it is not considered necessary to provide furnishings for the teacher's residence until early in the new fiscal year or prior to the opening of the school year in September, next.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa,
June 25, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of June 5 you enclosed Inspector Barry's report on his inspection of the Gitlakdamix Indian Day School and it is noted that he again recommends that the services of the teacher terminate on the 30th instant.

In your covering letter you make no special reference to the Inspector's recommendation but from the information contained in your letters of January 10 and February 19 it is evident that you have been in communication with Rt. Rev. Bishop Rix with a view to securing properly qualified teachers to take charge of this school during the academic year 1940-41.

I should appreciate your advising me as soon as you can conveniently do so what the prospects are for obtaining new teachers as it is apparent from the Inspector's report that Mr. Kinley's services are not very satisfactory.

It is also noted from the Inspector's report that he suggests that this school operate on a seven-month basis only; namely, from October 1 to April 30. This recommendation meets with our approval.

In the event of new teachers being obtained I would refer you to the last paragraph of official letter of February 13 last authorizing an expenditure for the purchase of furnishings for the teacher's quarters.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
EX'D.

Ottawa, August 28, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th instant, in which you seek authority to purchase the necessary furnishings for the Gitlakdamix Indian Day School, at a cost of approximately $800.

The files indicate that you were authorized to purchase these furnishings in departmental letter of February 13, 1940, the cost not to exceed $225. This authority was renewed in the last paragraph of departmental letter of June 25, 1940. It is desirable that the furnishings should be purchased by you and supplied at an early date.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

In the estimates of 1941-42, I asked for an appropriation to construct cement walls in the basement of the Gitlakdamix school, to prevent it from flooding. After heavy rains, the floor is covered with water varying in depth from a few inches to a foot.

The basement, which contains the furnace and is used as a store room for the wood, measures 38'x16'x8'. It has a cement floor and board walls which are leaking. It will be necessary to have the walls only one foot above the surrounding ground. A diagram is attached, giving the dimensions of each wall. The total measurement for an 8" wall is 14 cubic yards. The materials required are listed on form 37, which is attached herewith, showing the cost of same, together with a tender from McGaffery's for cement. The lumber can be purchased from the Aiyansh saw mill and the hardware from Gordon's Hardware at Prince Rupert. The approximate cost will be $475.00, which is much less than the amount shown in the estimates. Mr. Mitchell, the builder of the school figured on a cement wall completely around the school, whereas I consider it necessary to enclose only that portion which is used for the furnace and store room, the remainder of it is not excavated. Indian labor will be available about September 15th. As it should not take any more than one week to complete the job I would go to Gitlakdamix and stay until it was finished, as it is not possible to secure a white foreman. If the Department approves of the above I would recommend that an advance cheque for $250.00 be forwarded here, so that I may pay for the labor.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

September 3, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th ultimo requesting authority to expend $475.00 for the construction of a concrete basement for the Gitlakdamix School in order to prevent it from being flooded by heavy rains.

In reply I would advise that after discussion of this matter with Mr. Inspector Barry, the item was deleted from your estimates for the current fiscal year. Mr. Inspector Coleman informs me that when he visited the school he found there was a tendency for the ground at the rear of the school to drain towards the building and bring about the condition complained of but that he discussed with you the matter of constructing a drain behind the school to carry away this water to some low ground or a small creek to one side of the building. It appears to me that if this could be done and it would remedy the situation, that it would be far less expensive than the work which you proposed to undertake. It would be appreciated if you would advise me if any attempt was made to construct the drain in question.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Re: Gitlakdamix School

With reference to your letter of the 3rd inst., I beg to say that the ditch back of the school was cleared and deepened and it improved the situation as far as preventing water from going through the basement wall was concerned, and we had thought this was the only source of the trouble. The winter of 1941 Mr. Henderson discovered that the chief source of the flooding was through the front wall of the basement. I also verified this in October last.

It is possible that the down pipe on the eave trough which enters the drain pipe near the front wall of the basement is the cause of the trouble. If it is this could be remedied by having another outlet from the drain near the down pipe to the back ditch. This would mean running a ditch approximately 75 feet long, varying in depth from 2 to 6 feet. I think it would also be necessary to place a board drain in the ditch approximately 6 inches x 4 inches, and it may also be advisable when we have the ditch open near the school to put an extra lining of boards on the outside wall of the basement, arranging them so they would cover up the seams in the present wall.

It will require approximately 300 feet of rough lumber 1x12, 1x6 and 1x4. The approximate cost of the lumber would be $9.00, and it could be purchased at the Aiyansh sawmill. The labor would cost approximately $25.00 for this job. Nails and incidentals would amount to about $6.00.

I will delay my trip to Aiyansh until I receive word whether or not this work can be done.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

I received a wire and a letter from Miss Brunton, teacher at Aiyansh, in which she asks for the articles listed on Form 37.

We cannot purchase the grate and deck chair in Prince Rupert. The bureau and other material can be purchased locally for the prices that are listed. I recommend that all the article be purchased with the exception of the paint which she requires for the ceiling in the schoolroom, to give better light reflection. The ceiling is now oiled. I think this matter could be left until next year when I visit the school and make an investigation and an estimate of the labour. I would recommend that she be supplied with a gas lamp for the schoolroom.

I consider the bedroom bureau necessary as she claims that she has no place to keep her clothes. Unfortunately, there was none supplied with the original list of furnishings.

The deck chair he wishes is to be used as an easy chair. She states that the bottom is broken on the wicker chair which was supplied with the original furniture order. I will see if this can be repaired. It is not a comfortable chair, however, and I notice that Miss Brunton has a deformed back. It may be possible that the deck chair would be more comfortable for her.

I would suggest that the grate and deck chair be shipped care of us as we may be able to contact some party going up to Aiyansh. The next boat connecting with Aiyansh mail service will not be going up until the middle of December.

J. Gillett

I beg to forward herewith Mr. Indian Agent Gillett's letter of April 26th and Requisition for materials to construct a cement basement for the Aitkensh Indian Day School building.

Provision was made in the Estimates for an expenditure of $496.15 for this work, and it would be appreciated if you would advise if the funds were made available.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
I placed an item in 1944-45 estimates for $490.15 to have cement walls erected around the basement of the Alyansh Indian Day School. I would recommend that this be done in May of this year before the men leave for the fishing plants.

The cement could be purchased at Albert & Modaffery Ltd., the only local source, for $4.75 per barrel, f.o.b. Prince Rupert. The lumber can be purchased at Alyansh, and the nails and tar at Gordon's Hardware, Prince Rupert.

If I am authorized to have this work carried out, I would appreciate an accountable cheque for $284.00 for wages, lumber and river freight. I would appreciate an early reply so that I can make arrangements to have ten or twelve men remain in the village. I anticipate leaving here for Alyansh on the 22nd of May.

J.G. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Your 168-32-5 (WTI) of August 27th received having reference to voucher no. 290, freight on 150 lbs. of school supplies for the Gitlakdamix Indian Day School.

It should be explained that this charge of $1.95 is for transporting these goods 100 miles up the Nass River by Indian gas boat. The standard rate for all freight on this river is 1½¢ per pound. The item for 75¢ is for delivery at Aiyansh from the dock to the school. It is impossible to obtain freight receipts from Indians as they have no letterheads, neither are they licensed to carry freight. These supplies are taken up as a convenience to the Department by the Indians and their rates are really very reasonable. In view of this explanation, it is recommended that the account be paid.

Reference your 12-11-3 of May 30th, 1949, our file 1-11-3-166, Gitlakdamix Indian Day School repairs. Attached please find requisitions for material. Bids have been obtained from Gordon & Anderson Ltd. and Gordon's Hardware this city, which prices are the same as Vancouver, less 10%.

It is proposed to paint the roof of two coats as it is presently in extremely bad condition. This means a coverage of 6,000 ft² and will take 25 gallons of cedar tone shingle coating. It is recommended that the exterior walls be done with one coat of Martin-Senour undercoater no. 410 and a coat of 100% pure paint, cream. Windows, trim and porches will be done with no. 541 special green.

The interior is presently done in cedar V-joint and the place is dark and gloomy. It is planned to paint the entire interior with an coat of undercoater no. 410; the ceilings and walls with Ivory no. 595 with a cost of golden brown no. 588 on the walls four feet from the floor. The floors will be painted Brazil Green no. 527.

The teacherage will be painted throughout with an undercoat and a finish coat of Ivory with cream walls and a brown base, floors to be painted green.

At prices submitted by Gordon & Anderson Ltd., the material for the roof will cost $91.25; for the outside $189.75; for the interior $170.40 with an extra of $25.00 for brushes, turps, cleaner, etc. Total material cost $381.15.

I would also recommend that an Indian woman, Mrs. Alice Woods, age about 65, be employed by the teaching month at a monthly salary of some $5.00 to teach Basket Work. Ottawa, June 26th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

In reporting on his inspection of the Gitladamicks Indian Day School on the 5th ultimo, Inspector Barry writes, as follows:-

"I would also recommend that an Indian woman, Mrs. Alice Woods, age about 65, be employed by the teaching month at a monthly salary of some $5.00 to teach Basket Work. With the cost of the necessary materials the total grant which would be necessary to cover the suggested work in Arts and Crafts would not exceed the sum of $100.00 per year.

"I should like to see the girls working at these baskets on at least one afternoon per week. When and if an experienced teacher is employed here, some Vocational Training in the form of sewing, Etc., should also be taken up, but this is quite impossible under the present conditions."

The Department wishes to encourage basketry work and I would appreciate it if you would advise me if Mrs. Woods' services could be secured at the salary mentioned by Mr. Barry. You might also state if you could secure the necessary material at a cost of, approximately, $50.00.

Yours truly,

H. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

As is known to you, the settlement of Indian Salvationists known as Glen Vowell, near Hazelton, was established in 1895, and supplied with an Salvation Army Officer, Ensign Thorkildson, in October in 1899.

He has been very successful both in his missionary work among the Indians, and his educational efforts among the children. There is now a permanent population of 72 people in the place, whose behaviour has been most exemplary, and Ensign Thorkildson has erected on behalf of the Salvation Army, three buildings—a hall for meeting purposes, a dwelling house, and a school house. He has fully learned the native language during his stay, and has put forth every effort to teach the children. Our educational efforts however are much handicapped for the lack of funds to find books and the necessary material.

There are at present 26 children at the village of which 16 are of school age. On behalf of these children and in view of the commendable results already achieved, I would petition the Indian part of the Government, through you, to allow the Salvation Army at Glen Vowell the annual school grant as given in other missionary schools, and in order to enable our officers to teach the children more effectually in the future.

I have no doubt that this respectful request will be considered only just and in order, and will be dealt with favorably by the Government, and have your sincere endorsement.

I am, dear sir,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) Evangeline Booth

A Christmas Dream

By Major Margaret Balkwill

A fierce storm was raging in a great forest, on the borders of which stood the log hut of a Woodman.

The wind howled and shrieked and the snow blizzed upon the small window in sudden gusts. The ancient trees groaned and trembled, and the crackling of the fire and the sharp crack of broken branches could be heard as they were torn from the trees.

Inside, all was bright and warm and cheerful. The Woodman sat by the fire, resting after his day's work, while his little girl sat close by at his father's feet deep in the adventures of some old rabbits. From another room came the sound of a child's voice crying out piteously and fell in the hall or rush of the storm.

Presently the door opened and the simple cottage was filled with the light of a girl's grey eyes and lips that smiled reassuringly.

"I'm glad you're awake, father; it's worse at the back. I began to wonder if it would blow the hut down."

Hildegarde spoke the words, set a flaming dish on the small round table that stood near the fire beside her father's chair, that she might cheer him up, and then she began to brush his hair daintily, though her eyes were large with anxiety.

"No, no, child," said the Woodman, laying his hand gently on her shoulder. "I am better now. You must go to bed, my dear, and I will turn to the supper table and begin ladling out the soup into the plates. We have a nice fire somewhere, but it is a poor storm than this."

The home is safe enough, so don't fear."

"It is strange that they should come," said the Woodman, turning his head towards the door. "No, not a bit afraid father—but then I'm a boy, aren't I? I couldn't help."

"Not more of spiders?" asked Hildegarde softly.

"Spiders," said Ivan, reddening, "of course not."

"It's not so very long are you come begging me to take one off your pillow because you didn't like the feel of it, and I had to take it away," laughed the girl.

"Oh that's different, that's a girl's work," and Ivan raised a spoonful of the delicious soup to his lips.

A silence fell, a silence that comes for a second or two in the midst of the greatest storm when for a moment the wind sweeps away only to return with redoubled fury.

The children were bent upon each other, for the splintering and tearing sounds in the forest were deafening. Two years ago the children had lost their mother, and Ivan, the eldest, the wife he had loved so well, since that time little Hildegarde had done her best to make her father happy and to be a mother to him. She scrubbed and washed and cooked and tended and all day sang about her mother and her father.

She gathered sticks for the fire and berries in their season and knew where the birds' nests were and where the wild flowers grew. The children were seldom lonely though their father was away all day. Sometimes he took them with him, but they never went far, for though they were poor, they were frugal and had enough.

As the bell came for a moment Ivan pushed back his plate and spoon, but Hildegarde held up her hand.

"Listen!" she said, "what was that?"

"Noticed it," the Woodman answered, and said her father that he would pick up a paper and sat down in his chair by the fire. "Best try and tell."

"That, father, I heard a knock." Hildegarde said with startled eyes. "Who can it be—and to-night?"

"You are dreaming, Hildegarde. Let's wash up and target the outside, it's easy enough in here," said the little boy, seeing that his sister was really alarmed.

"But I'm sure I heard a knock. There it is again," cried Hildegarde.

This time they had all heard it, and the Woodman rose to his feet. "I'll see, but I expect it's only the trees. No one comes at night."

As he spoke, he took down the heavy wooden latch and opened the door, but the furious wind burst the door open, knocking down little Ivan with its force and almost hurled into the street. The Woodman rushed out, covered with snow and drenched to the skin.

"Hildegarde—Hildegarde!" called the man over and over, but though he shouted at the top of his voice, no sound was heard.

But Hildegarde, who at first had stood with eyes wide open watching, moved forward and caught the child in her arms as he fell whilst her father struggled with the door. After some moments of effort, the door was closed, and then silent with the effort and astonishment, he stood looking down at the child who was sobbing in his hands. The snow was melting and little streams of water began to run over the child's cheeks. His golden hair hung uncerced and damp, his face, which was very beautiful, was wet with tears.

"Give me some of the broth," he said, and the child gave him some of the soup.

So lovingly and carefully, they all waited on the little stranger until the storm abated. No sooner was the child's head on the pillows than he was asleep.

"Who is he? Where does he come from?" asked the Woodman, who was standing by the fire and looking thoughtfully down into it.

"He must have got lost in the forest, though I am not sure as to who he can be. I know all the people around, and he belongs to none of them. And I've heard that there is a mysterious castle that will be in sore trouble to-night, I reckon, over him. When the storm has lessened I will go and find out. Now I must go to bed and sleep."

They all slept at last, worn out by the storm and the excitement of the night. When the sun shone late and the wind was gone; the sun was shining over the soaking earth, but the little bed in the corner of the Woodman's room was empty.

No trace was to be found of the child who had sought refuge in the hut. The Woodman visited the neighbors poor and rich, but no one knew the child or had heard of any like him in the region of the forest.

Many weeks had passed. Snow and wind and cold had given place to warm days, sunshine and flowers. Hildegarde and Ivan often talked of the beautiful stranger who came by night, as they played in the forest or worked at home.

"How did he get out of the hut, Hilde?" asked Ivan one day for the hundredth time of his sister.

"I don't know," replied Hildegarde lightly, "you have done that, Ivan, when father has locked the door by mistake."

"Yes, but how could he find out the secret of the hut?"

"Boys know everything, don't they?" returned his sister, mischievously. "See, Ivan, father, he sat there for a minute and then ran towards the hut."

"Have you heard any music, children?" asked the Woodman as the painting boy and girl reached the hut. Ivan was standing at the door of the hut listening.

"Music? No, where?"

"Hush, Ivan, I hear it," whispered Hildegarde, and Ivan turned pale.

In the distance exquisite strains of music could be faintly heard—growing more distinct each moment, until it seemed as though it came once in the forest whence the sounds came, eyes that grew wide in astonishment and bright with wonder, and then the music died away, and the stillness returned.

Nearer and louder grew the music and then a procession of richly robed figures appeared. They were playing as they walked, and at their head and a little in advance moved the figure of a young girl, whose dress was white, richly embroidered in silver and in one hand he held the branch of a tree.

"Father, it's the boy—the boy who came to us," stammered Hildegarde. "What does it mean?"

"Oh father," the Woodman said as he bowed his head to stand, and the beautiful boy, advancing alone, came and stood straight and noble before the Woodman and his children—and spoke.

"Sir," he said, and his voice was like an echo of the sweetest music. "I have come to thank you for your kindness to me. I know you are ungrateful, but I could not come before to thank you on behalf of my Father and myself for your kindness to my little friend. To show you how we appreciate your kindness to a stranger I have brought you a gift. To-day this and every day for evermore, and on the anniversary of the day you saved my life this branch will bear golden fruit for you and yours."

A wonderful radiance of light seemed irradiated his face, and fell upon the little group who stood speechless as he turned away and took up his place at the head of the procession. Amid strains of music the boy and his followers passed out of sight.

Thus did I dream on Christmas eve, and I wouldn't be too much told.

If I hope that it brings to you the same quality of spiritual meditation upon it provides for me, then am I holding a big hope for you this Christmas tide.
Amongst the Redskins

Glad Tidings Proclaimed in Northern British Columbia and Alaska

What a happy task to write of Alaska, Northern British Columbia, and their native peoples, "Natives." And for here be true natives. We are wont to call citizens of the Southern Republic by the name of "Americans," whereas they are really "U.S.-statans." But here among the sea-girt islets and along the rock-bound coasts of the north we have found the true Americans.

And, be it known, the peoples of the land have a long history and pedigree of which we whites scarce can boast. Long before the intrepid De Soto followed the winding Mississippi northward, the great Balboa first cast eyes upon the mighty Pacific; yes, and even centuries before the dauntless viking Leif Ericson set foot upon the new world, the proud red men of the north had subdued the people of Alaska in possession of an unique civilization. Here the proud tribal chiefs smoked their pipes of peace, here conflicting tribes met in death-dealing battle, here the brave died and here the stories of the past were told; here these pre-historic redmen tilled the soil and bartered their furs; here the black-eyed, intelligent Indian chief, freed from ancient superstition, the forbidden charms of the evil eye, showed them skin shirts adorned with the art of crude native warfare. Yes, and off the primeval forests were heard the weird funeral chants, as one by one the proud warriors of their race were gathered to their fathers. Thus did the red men of the north, with buckles numberless enliven the New Land.

They were a great people whose first American traits they had no cause to hide. They knew the friendships that unites the brothers of the climate to believe in the Infinite—be those children of the north-west to bend knee to tolerate gods, pray to the sun's fiery orb, and suffer tortuous persecutions under intolerable conditions.

It was among such a people that, in 1879, the Rev. Robert Tomlinson boldly attempted to establish a Protestant Mission. Not many miles from where the Indians had been now gathered, Mr. Tomlinson had sought to establish a distinctly Christian village, where all who would renounce their idols might occupy claims of land unmolested. As a young bride came to her husband's side, so did the missionary face the perils etc. Mrs. Tomlinson still lives, and it is her delight to narrate or those thrilling early day conquests. It will interest readers to know that two hundred years hence, when the white man has disappeared, they help in furthering the splendid work which their parents pioneered.

It was about 1880 that a Salvation Army Captain was first sent to command operations among the Indians. Glen Vowell, who founded the first Salvation Army village, was the first point of attack. To-day, after twenty-four years of effort we may boast of a thriving Army of uniformed Salvationists, who have erected churches, schools, hospitals, orphanages, charitable Officers' Quarters and School-houses. The acorn has become an oak.

Adjutant Jackson of Regina, who was stationed for a number of years in Alaska, tells a rather romantic story of an heroic Indian maiden who frustrated the murderous schemes of her own people, that they might one day have a "white teacher" sent them.

In a certain village of the upper Skeena River there grew a legend of the white man's influence, and both a plan and means were devised to "white" village and massacre the people. At the most, there were but a handful of settlers, who could make but little resistance against the surging tide of savagery. It was known that the Indians who were coming, who had met with The Salvation Army at the Coast, and among them was a young girl who refused to slip away and influence the Indians against the proposed attack. Also, with her was her village friend, The Army to whom she send teachers to her people. She realized that any assault upon the white men could make the impossible, and would place great limitations on her tribe. Her daring and excellent conduct led the way in the midst of the rushing Skeena, where her canoe was safely fastened, and in the dead of night crossed those perilous waters, then, on foot, traversed her way sacred charge, she is helping to spread the glad tidings of Him Whose Name we are now commemorating.

Dear Ensign Yarlett:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the establishment of a small boarding school for Salvation Army Indian children at Glen Vowell. It is true that very effective educational work can be carried on when children are taken into residence; but before the Department sanctions the scheme or gives favourable consideration to a grant for current expenses, we must be satisfied that proper facilities will be provided and that suitable care and supervision will be given. Further, I should state the other churches have found the small boarding school a constant source of expense even and above whatever grant the Department can allow. I therefore wish to urge you and the Army officers to give very careful consideration before undertaking any expenditure.

You should indicate how many children you propose to maintain and you should forward a report concerning the building you would use. It will be necessary to know the size of the children's dormitories, something of the heating, lighting, fire protection, water supply, sewage disposal or other sanitary arrangements. The number and duties of the staff should be indicated. I assume that, at the outset, you intend to look after some of the pupils of the Glen Vowell Indian Day School and that they will take their classes as formerly. I also understand that it would be only for part of the school year that the arrangement would be necessary. The Department does not wish to discourage any improvement in the educational work that you are doing; but the funds at our disposal do not permit us to assist with the establishment and maintenance of small boarding schools, located wherever a few children appear to require residence facilities while attending school.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Peacock:

Owing to conditions now confronting us it was only found possible to provide in the current year's appropriation an amount sufficient to pay the salaries of teachers of Indian day schools for a period of nine months during the current fiscal year. This applies to all Indian day schools in Canada.
