I would refer to your letter of July 17, 1944, File 151-13-1, approving of the appointment of Captain A.S. Hagglund as teacher at Glen Vowell Day School and enclose herewith a letter dated the 25th instant received from Lieut. Colonel Matt. Junker advising that his Headquarters feel it necessary to move Captain Hagglund and replace him by Captain Ethel Brierly. His services have been very satisfactory.

Section 155 (j) of the B.C. Provincial "School Act" provides for a teacher giving thirty days notice of his resignation, which period of notice shall terminate with the close of the school term. I believe the usual penalty is suspension of the teacher's certificate. This provision is, of course, to avoid disturbance of school routine during the term.

In the interests of our educational work, I feel that the Salvation Army authorities should refrain, as much as possible, from removing these teachers during the term. They apparently fail to realize that they are in the employ of the Department while engaged at these day schools and would also be subject as our employees to the requirements of the Selective Service Branch. If there is some urgent necessity for the employment of the teacher's services elsewhere, which, in this case, has not so far been indicated, then the Department is entitled to suitable representations.

It was anticipated that the Salvation Army would nominate Captain Ethel Brierly for the position of teacher at Gwinsha School, which has not yet been filled.

This would, no doubt, be an opportune time to discuss the nature and term of these appointments with Salvation Army Headquarters at Toronto.

Major D M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

I enclose herewith the nomination of Brigadier J.T. Gillinham, dated 13th inst. of John Orman Cooper as teacher for the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, who has just arrived and submitted enclosed application of the 22nd inst. for the position.

I have interviewed Mr. Cooper and as we are unable to secure a certificated teacher for the position I would recommend his appointment on a temporary basis as he appears very well qualified apart from professional standing. The "temporary" appointment only is recommended as I do not consider we should consider the more or less permanent retention of other than qualified educational personnel.

I am not recommending any salary as I do not have with me a copy of the "Cameron Report". It should be kept in mind, however, that the Salvation Army built the school and teacherage at their own expense and maintained them except for a few minor repairs during the past year or so. I understand these "Army" teachers turn their salaries back into the "Army" work, retaining only their actual needs.

It will be noted that Mr. Cooper is single but is engaged to be married as soon as he can secure "Army" consent. In my opinion married status on these Reserves is preferable.

I would recommend his appointment.

(James Coleman)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

I enclose a copy of a letter received from Mr. J.O. Cooper teacher at the Glen Vowell Indian Day School.

The teacher has apparently been paid a salary which included the rental of the Salvation Army buildings at that point, one of which we use as a school and the other, the Mission House, is tenanted by the teacher who in recent years has always been a member of the Salvation Army.

The matter of Welfare teachers is one which is difficult to settle without reference to the Indian Health Service from whom I have recently requested a decision as to the continued establishment of dispensers at each of several reserves. At the present time some teachers and missionaries are dispensing drugs and rendering some medical assistance to the Indians without any additional remuneration at all and I feel that some provision should be made for a nominal compensation to these persons. This should properly of course be paid by the Department of Health and Welfare.

Our file shows a copy of a letter sent to you by the Treasury Branch dated November 1st with which was enclosed cheque No. A46-60069 issued in your favour in the amount of $93.52 being refund of Retirement Fund Account.

The letter was addressed to you c/o The Salvation Army, 12 Springdale St., St. Johns, Newfoundland which was the address given to us by Superintendent Boys in a letter dated September 9th.

We suggest that you write to the Salvation Army at St. Johns concerning your cheque. If you do not receive it, please let us hear from you.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Heary
Superintendent of Education.

c/o to Mr. Boys.
November 27, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,

Glen Vowell Indian Day School

On September 25 you wrote concerning a replacement for Mr. John O. Cooper, formerly teacher at the above school.

Please find attached Application for Employment forms, Employee Questionnaire forms and Income Tax forms. These forms reached the Department with no covering letter and apparently have lain on a file for some time now. In view of the fact that these have not passed through your office, they are being sent to you for comment.

We note that, unfortunately, Mrs. Jarrett has no teaching experience nor qualifications whatsoever. I would suggest that representations be made to the Salvation Army and that they be advised that the Department is most anxious to have only qualified and experienced teachers in its schools. We feel that Mrs. Jarrett, while willing enough probably, will only be a stop-gap appointment and that the pupils can only make but limited progress under her direction.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Glen Vowell Indian Day School

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of November 27th concerning the employment of Mrs. E. W. Jarrett at the above mentioned school.

Ottawa, April 11, 1925.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing the resignation of Capt. R. Boyes as teacher of the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, and informing the Department that the Salvation Army Headquarters have appointed Capt. Alice E. Kenny to succeed him.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Kenny. We note that she commenced duties on the 2nd instant, also that she has had experience in Indian schools. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $85 per teaching month. Please inform Miss Kenny of the Department's approval of her appointment and the salary allowed. It is hoped that she will meet with every success in the work at Glen Vowell.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. Hyde Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

Knowing that you have always shown a practical interest in the welfare of Glen Vowell, and that you also are fully acquainted with the progress made from the very beginning of the settlement, so it will not be necessary for me to go into lengthy explanations, I simply desire herewith to lay a matter of very great importance to the Village, before you, and your Department, in the hope that you will be able to help us.

As you are aware, I came to Glen Vowell in the fall of 1899. And the Village - if it could then be called such - was composed of the name, and three temporary log cabins. I shall not enlarge on the hardships in connection with the building up of a new Town, as that can only be understood by those who have had a similar experience. It will suffice to say, that with a lot of unstable people only, at your back, misunderstood by some, doubted as to the final outcome of the undertaking, by more, with no means at my disposal, and practically no outside help - you will understand that I have had to do many things temporarily, that at the time could have been done permanently.

First of all, when arriving here I saw that my hope would lie in educating the children and younger people, to the best of my ability, realizing that failing there, I would fail irretrievably. Consequently I erected a small log-house for a school, even before having a comfortable dwelling myself. In course of time it proved too small, and although
not in a position, from a financial standpoint, to build a better house, yet seeing to wait until I should be, would be disastrous to the work - I did manage to build another frame building, 16' x 24', which we have been using as a school building now since 1904.

But now I am confronted by the same difficulty again viz., the building being too small and not properly ventilated, in fact altogether inadequate to accommodate the steady increasing number of children here.

Therefore dear Sir, feeling that personally, I have done all that it was possible for me to do under the circumstances, and fully believing that it is not only your desire; but also the desire of the Department you represent, that the children should have a chance, and be properly taught in a proper building, where health and sanitary conditions would be all that could be expected - I herewith take the liberty to ask for your help and influence to secure a school building for Glen Voell, at the earliest possible date.

Respectfully yours,

J.P. Thorvaldson

Sir,

Sir,

Authority Requisition

I have the honour to state herewith that the teacher of the Glen Vowell Indian Day School, Miss Pearl Jackson, represented to me whilst there, that the play-ground environing that school is much in need of being levelled up.

The same, covering about an acre, I found encumbered with three large stumps, and some of lesser size, and with many knolls and hollows, which could be removed and the ground be made perfectly smooth at the reasonable expense, by contract, of $15.00; and beg to request that by the Department I may be authorized to expend that amount in order to have remedied all of these defects, and the ground made wholly available for that purpose; and in concluding beg to add that the self-same subject has previously been discussed with Mr. Inspector Tyson, and whereat an assistance in that respect had been promised.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honour to state that owing to an overcrowded condition of the Glen Vowell Indian Day School building, owned by the Salvation organization, Brigadier Sowten brought up the subject of having, if possible, the building enlarged by making it wider, but upon my suggestion that it be cheaper by lengthening it he was convinced of this being a good plan.

Ensign H. K. Jackson, the missionary of that locality gave me a letter of the 26th ultimo, and attached thereto an estimate of costs, complete, and which papers I beg to enclose herewith proving the total cost to be $229.40.

Since the the Glen Vowell school building very much needs remedying in that respect, and the school has all along been and is doing splendid work, and consider the expense to be incurred reasonable, and the work is calculated to be done during the coming holidays, I would respectfully recommend the authority to be granted to the measure here proposed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

REPORT OF INSPECTOR TYSON ON SCHOOLS IN NORTHERN INSPECTORATE

GLEN VOWELL DAY SCHOOL.

The building here is too small for school purposes and unsuitable for winter weather. In my previous report, I suggested that a new school should be built at this village but as this is not feasible this year on account of financial conditions, I would recommend that the building be lengthened fifteen feet at an estimated expenditure of about $200 or $225.

Should this improvement be carried out the building would probably answer the purposes for a year or two.

Report dated, June 7th, 1916.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands, and if you consider it advisable to purchase the second-hand stove you may do so at the price quoted by you.
